verses.sanskrit: मदनुग्रहाय परमं गुह्यमध्यात्मसञ्ज्ञितम् | यत्त्वयोक्तं वचस्तेन मोहोऽयं विगतो मम ||
verses.transliteration: mad-anugrahāya paramaṃ guhyam adhyātmasañjñitam | yat tvayoktaṃ vacas tena moho'yam vigato mama ||
verses.translation: That supreme secret of the Self, called Adhyatma, which You have spoken out of grace for me — by that discourse of Yours, this delusion of mine has completely departed.

word_breakdown.meaning: out of grace for me / for my benefit
called adhyatma / pertaining to the Self

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna begins Chapter 11 with gratitude — a beautiful sign that the teaching of Chapters 1 through 10 has truly entered his heart. He says 'moho'yam vigato mama' — 'this delusion of mine is gone.' This is the first fruit of satsang with a true teacher: confusion lifts. In our own lives, when we sit with a scripture or a wise person and something suddenly becomes clear, that moment of clarity is exactly what Arjuna describes here. The teaching was given 'mad-anugrahāya,' out of grace, not because Arjuna deserved it but because Krishna loved him. Grace precedes understanding.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 1 is Arjuna's acknowledgment that the Adhyātma-vidyā — the knowledge of the Self — has accomplished its primary purpose: the removal of moha, delusion. In Vedantic terms, moha is avidyā, the superimposition of the not-Self upon the Self. Arjuna's statement 'vigato mama mohaḥ' echoes the Vedantic declaration of liberation: the fundamental confusion has ended. Yet Arjuna proceeds to ask for the cosmic vision, which shows that intellectual understanding of the Self is one thing, and a direct, overwhelming experience of God's totality is another. Shankaracharya notes that this verse establishes Arjuna's qualifications (adhikāra) for receiving the supreme vision.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's opening words reveal a soul prepared for the ultimate revelation. The 'supreme secret' that has been imparted is the Adhyātma — the science of the indwelling Self, that spark of Cosmic Consciousness residing in every creature. When this knowledge truly illumines the mind, delusion dissolves as naturally as darkness dissolves at sunrise. Arjuna is not merely saying the words — he has meditated on Krishna's teachings and experienced an inner shift. This is the difference between theoretical understanding and genuine realization: something moves inside, something releases. This receptive gratitude is itself a form of devotion.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna begins his speech acknowledging that the supreme and most secret knowledge — termed 'adhyātmasañjñitam,' pertaining to the individual Self and its relation to the Supreme — has been mercifully bestowed upon him by Bhagavan. The word 'mad-anugrahāya' establishes that divine knowledge is always a gift of grace (anugraha), not a product of mere intellectual effort alone. The dispelling of moha (delusion) is the direct result of hearing the truth from the mouth of the Sadguru. This verse demonstrates the proper attitude of a disciple: acknowledging the teacher, acknowledging the teaching, and reporting the inner result.

verses.sanskrit: भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया | त्वत्तः कमलपत्राक्ष माहात्म्यमपि चाव्ययम् ||
verses.transliteration: bhavāpyayau hi bhūtānāṃ śrutau vistaraśo mayā | tvattaḥ kamalāpatrākṣa māhātmyam api cāvyayam ||
verses.translation: I have heard in detail from You about the origin and dissolution of all beings, O lotus-eyed one, and also about Your inexhaustible greatness.

word_breakdown.meaning: dissolution / disappearance / merging back (dual with bhava)

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna says: 'I have heard about Your creation and dissolution of all beings, and about Your inexhaustible greatness.' He is summarizing what he has absorbed from Chapters 7 through 10. The tender address 'kamalāpatrākṣa' — O lotus-eyed one — breaks your heart a little. In the midst of a profound metaphysical inquiry, Arjuna pauses to call Krishna 'lotus-eyed.' This is bhakti woven into jñāna. The devotee cannot speak of God for long without some term of endearment slipping in. And notice the word 'avyayam' — inexhaustible. No matter how much of God's glory you hear, it is never exhausted. That is the nature of the Infinite.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna is establishing the context for his request: I have received the teaching of Chapters 7–10 — the knowledge of God's manifestation (bhava) and dissolution (apyaya) of all existence, and the Vibhūti-yoga that described His inexhaustible greatness. But hearing about the cosmic form is different from seeing it. This is the Vedantic distinction between śravaṇa (hearing) and aparokṣānubhūti (direct experience). Arjuna has had the śravaṇa — now he wants the direct vision. The beautiful epithet 'kamalāpatrākṣa' hints at Krishna's divine beauty, setting up the contrast with the terrifying grandeur of the Vishvarūpa about to be revealed.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna recounts what he has learned: the great cycles of cosmic manifestation and dissolution described in Chapters 9 and 10, and the divine glories catalogued in the Vibhūti Yoga. The word 'avyayam' — inexhaustible, imperishable — is key: God's greatness can be spoken of endlessly and yet never fully captured in words. Arjuna senses this and desires to go beyond words into direct vision. The lovely epithet 'lotus-eyed' reminds us that God is not only the vast impersonal Absolute but also the most beautiful, most intimate Presence, whose every feature has been lovingly contemplated by generations of devotees.
commentary.goyandka: In this verse Arjuna demonstrates that he has been an attentive and grateful student. The dual form 'bhavāpyayau' (origin-dissolution) refers to the cycles of sṛṣṭi and pralaya detailed in Chapters 7, 8, and 9. The term 'māhātmyam avyayam' — the imperishable greatness — points to the divine glories systematically presented in Chapter 10. The address 'kamalāpatrākṣa' is a traditional Vaiṣṇava epithet of Bhagavan Viṣṇu-Krishna, indicating Arjuna's awareness of Krishna's divine nature even before the Vishvarūpa is revealed.

verses.sanskrit: एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर | द्रष्टुमिच्छामि ते रूपमैश्वरं पुरुषोत्तम ||
verses.transliteration: evam etad yathāttha tvam ātmānaṃ parameśvara | draṣṭum icchāmi te rūpam aiśvaraṃ puruṣottama ||
verses.translation: Even as You have declared Yourself to be, O Supreme Lord — I desire to see Your divine, lordly form (aiśvara rūpa), O Supreme Person.

word_breakdown.meaning: even so / just as this is
divine / lordly / pertaining to the Lord

commentary.dadaji: Here Arjuna makes the formal request: 'I believe everything You have told me about Yourself — now I want to see it.' This is the turning point. Knowledge has done its work; now the heart demands experience. There is a phrase worth savoring: 'yathāttha tvam ātmānam' — 'as You have declared Yourself to be.' Arjuna is not doubting Krishna. He accepts the teaching completely. But there is a difference between accepting a description of the ocean and standing on the shore with waves crashing around you. The address 'puruṣottama' — the Highest Person — is the same title used throughout Chapter 15. Arjuna calls on the Highest Person to reveal Himself fully.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 3 contains an important phrase: 'evam etad yathāttha' — 'even as You have declared.' This is śraddhā — faith. Arjuna is not a skeptic demanding proof. He accepts Krishna's self-description completely. Yet he makes the request for the aiśvara rūpa — the 'lordly form.' In Vedantic terms, this is the saguṇa Brahman — the Absolute as endowed with all divine qualities (aiśvarya: lordliness, omnipotence). The two epithets frame this verse: 'parameśvara' (O Supreme Lord) acknowledges Krishna's sovereignty, and 'puruṣottama' (O Supreme Person) acknowledges Krishna as the Highest among all beings, beyond both perishable and imperishable, as described in Chapter 15.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's request is the universal spiritual hunger: 'I have heard about You — now I want to see You.' Every sincere devotee carries this longing. The aiśvara rūpa — the lordly, divine form — is the vision of God as the Cosmic Reality underlying all of creation. The two names Arjuna uses are profound: 'Parameśvara' — the Supreme Ruler of the universe — and 'Puruṣottama' — the Supreme Consciousness that transcends even the distinction between the mutable and the immutable. Arjuna is asking to see, in a single moment of direct perception, what it means for one Consciousness to contain all of existence.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's request is characterized by a beautiful combination of acceptance and aspiration. He first declares full acceptance — 'evam etad yathāttha tvam ātmānam' — acknowledging without reservation that Krishna has accurately described His own nature. Then comes the desire: 'draṣṭum icchāmi te rūpam aiśvaram' — to see the aiśvara rūpa, the form that is the concrete manifestation of God's omnipotence (aiśvarya). Arjuna's humility and faith are exemplary: he does not demand proof but requests the experience as a grace.

verses.sanskrit: मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो | योगेश्वर ततो मे त्वं दर्शयात्मानमव्ययम् ||
verses.transliteration: manyase yadi tac chakyaṃ mayā draṣṭum iti prabho | yogeśvara tato me tvaṃ darśayātmānam avyayam ||
verses.translation: If You think it is possible for me to see it, O Lord — then, O Master of Yoga, show me Your imperishable Self.

word_breakdown.meaning: O Master of Yoga / O Lord of Yoga

commentary.dadaji: What a beautiful humility shines in this verse! Arjuna does not say 'Show me Your form' — he says 'If You think it is possible for me to see it, then show me.' He defers entirely to Krishna's judgment. He knows that not all experiences are available to all people at all times. A human eye cannot look directly at the sun; perhaps a human soul cannot bear all visions of the Divine. Arjuna surrenders this to Krishna: 'You decide, O Lord — if I am ready, show me.' The address 'yogeśvara' — Master of Yoga — is perfect here, because what Arjuna is asking for requires the greatest yogic power: the ability to grant divine sight to another person.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse reveals Arjuna's complete surrender to the Guru. The conditional 'manyase yadi' — 'if You think it possible' — is not weakness but wisdom. In Vedānta, the direct experience of Brahman is not available simply by desire; the teacher must judge the student's readiness. Arjuna acknowledges this by placing the decision entirely in Krishna's hands. The epithet 'yogeśvara' — Lord of Yoga — is used for the one who has mastery over all yogic powers and who can, by grace, transmit extraordinary experience to a prepared disciple. The phrase 'avyayam ātmānam' — 'Your imperishable Self' — suggests Arjuna wants not just a spectacle but a vision of the eternal, unchanging divine reality.
commentary.yogananda: In this verse Arjuna demonstrates the spiritual virtue of non-presumption. He desires intensely, yet he holds his desire lightly, offering it to God's will: 'If You think I can bear the vision, grant it to me.' This is the perfect attitude of the devotee: burning longing combined with complete surrender of the outcome. The title 'yogeśvara' reminds us that true Yoga — union with God — is not merely a human practice but a divine gift. Krishna, as the Lord of Yoga, is the one who grants the ultimate yogic experience: seeing all of creation as one divine form. The word 'avyayam' — imperishable — reveals what Arjuna is ultimately seeking: not a temporary phenomenon but the eternal ground of being.
commentary.goyandka: This verse concludes Arjuna's request with admirable humility and surrender. 'Manyase yadi' — 'if You consider it appropriate' — reflects the proper relationship between the disciple and the omniscient Guru. The disciple does not impose his desires; he offers them for the teacher's consideration. The use of 'yogeśvara' — Lord of all Yoga — acknowledges that the ability to reveal the Vishvarūpa is itself a supreme yogic power uniquely belonging to Bhagavan. 'Avyayam ātmānam' refers to Krishna's true, eternal nature as the Imperishable Brahman — it is not merely a spectacular outer form that Arjuna seeks but a direct encounter with the Undying Reality.

verses.sanskrit: पश्य मे पार्थ रूपाणि शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः | नानाविधानि दिव्यानि नानावर्णाकृतीनि च ||
verses.transliteration: paśya me pārtha rūpāṇi śataśo'tha sahasraśaḥ | nānāvidhāni divyāni nānāvarṇākṛtīni ca ||
verses.translation: Behold, O Partha, My hundreds and thousands of forms — of various kinds, divine, of various colors and shapes.

word_breakdown.meaning: O Partha / O son of Pritha (Arjuna)

commentary.dadaji: Krishna's response begins with a single electrifying word: 'paśya' — Behold! After Arjuna's four verses of careful, humble preparation, God responds with a command of immediate directness. 'Hundreds and thousands of forms' — this is not exaggeration; this is the literal truth of how God appears in existence. Every blade of grass, every flash of lightning, every human face is one of those forms. Krishna is not preparing Arjuna for a vision of something outside the world; He is about to reveal the world itself as His body. The word 'divyāni' — divine — tells us that even the forms we think are ordinary are actually divine, if we could only see with the right eyes.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Krishna's response begins with the imperative 'paśya' — a direct command to shift perception. This is the Guru granting the disciple an immediate upgrade in consciousness. The 'hundreds and thousands of forms' represent the infinite multiplicity of existence — what the Upanishads call the 'many names and forms' (nāmarūpa) through which Brahman manifests. From the Advaita perspective, these countless forms are not different from Brahman but are Brahman appearing as the phenomenal world. The vision Krishna is about to grant is not a hallucination but the deepest truth: all of this multiplicity is One. 'Nānāvarṇākṛtīni' — various colors and shapes — evokes the dazzling diversity of the manifest universe.
commentary.yogananda: With a single commanding word — 'Behold!' — the cosmic vision begins. Krishna invites Arjuna to see what the ordinary senses cannot perceive: the Divine Life pulsing through every form in existence. 'Hundreds and thousands of forms' is not rhetorical; it is literal. Every star, every atom, every consciousness is a form of God. The word 'divyāni' — divine — is the key: what appears ordinary to the sleeping eye appears divine to the awakened one. Great yogis in states of samādhi describe exactly this vision: the entire universe luminous, vibrant, alive with one Presence wearing infinite costumes of color and shape. Arjuna is about to have this cosmic experience.
commentary.goyandka: With this verse, Bhagavan graciously accepts Arjuna's request and begins the revelation of the Vishvarūpa. The imperative 'paśya' — Behold — marks the transition from philosophical teaching to direct divine revelation. 'Śataśaḥ sahasraśaḥ' (hundreds and thousands) is a Vedic idiom for numberless multitudes. The word 'divyāni' indicates that these forms are not perceivable by ordinary sensory means but only by the divinely granted vision that will be conferred in verse 8. 'Nānāvarṇākṛtīni' — various colors and configurations — reflects the traditional description of the cosmic form found in the Purāṇas, particularly the Viṣṇu Purāṇa and Bhāgavata Purāṇa.

verses.sanskrit: पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्विनौ मरुतस्तथा | बहून्यदृष्टपूर्वाणि पश्याश्चर्याणि भारत ||
verses.transliteration: paśyādityān vasūn rudrān aśvinau marutas tathā | bahūny adṛṣṭapūrvāṇi paśyāścaryāṇi bhārata ||
verses.translation: Behold the Ādityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Aśvins, and also the Maruts; behold many wonders never seen before, O Bhārata (Arjuna).

word_breakdown.meaning: the Ādityas — twelve solar deities, sons of Aditi
the Rudras — eleven forms of Shiva, deities of storm and dissolution
the two Aśvins — twin divine physicians of the gods
the Maruts — wind deities, Indra's companions
O Bhārata / O descendant of Bhārata (Arjuna)

commentary.dadaji: Now Krishna begins listing the specific divine beings present in the cosmic vision. These are not mythological abstractions — the Ādityas, Vasus, Rudras, Aśvins, and Maruts are the invisible powers that run the universe: the forces of light, elemental nature, transformation, healing, and wind. When we see the sun rise, we are seeing an Āditya. When the wind blows, the Maruts are at work. Krishna is saying: all of these powers that sustain the cosmos — they are all Me. And not just these — 'many wonders never before seen.' There are dimensions of reality that no human eye has ever witnessed. Arjuna is about to see them all at once.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse catalogs the major classes of devas — divine cosmic powers — that will be visible in the Vishvarūpa. From a Vedantic standpoint, these devas are not independent realities but projections of the one Brahman appearing as differentiated cosmic functions. The Ādityas are aspects of solar consciousness; the Vasus are elemental principles; the eleven Rudras are powers of transformation; the Aśvins represent healing and duality; the Maruts represent the vital forces that animate creation. The phrase 'adṛṣṭapūrvāṇi āścaryāṇi' — wonders never seen before — acknowledges that the Vishvarūpa transcends even the known categories of cosmic reality.
commentary.yogananda: The cosmic vision includes the entire pantheon of divine powers: the Ādityas who sustain the cycles of time, the Vasus who underlie the material elements, the Rudras who preside over transformation, the Aśvins who heal and harmonize, and the Maruts who channel the vital energies of the cosmos. These are not merely mythological figures but represent real hierarchies of conscious divine intelligence governing the universe from behind the scenes. 'Never before seen' is remarkable — it suggests that the full extent of cosmic reality exceeds even the visionary capacities that human beings ordinarily develop through spiritual practice.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavan enumerates the principal classes of devas forming part of the Vishvarūpa. The twelve Ādityas preside over the months of the year; the eight Vasus correspond to elemental principles; the eleven Rudras are presiding deities of the eleven life-forces; the two Aśvins tend to health and completeness; the forty-nine Maruts are the storm-winds as divine powers. The Gita here confirms that all these deities, worshipped separately in various Vedic traditions, are simultaneously present as aspects of Krishna's one divine body. 'Adṛṣṭapūrvāṇi āścaryāṇi' — previously unseen wonders — points to the unprecedented nature of this revelation.

verses.sanskrit: इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम् | मम देहे गुडाकेश यच्चान्यद्द्रष्टुमिच्छसि ||
verses.transliteration: ihaikasthaṃ jagat kṛtsnaṃ paśyādya sacarācaram | mama dehe guḍākeśa yac cānyad draṣṭum icchasi ||
verses.translation: Behold now, O Guḍākeśa, the entire universe — with all moving and unmoving beings — standing in one place in My body, and whatever else you wish to see.

word_breakdown.meaning: in My body / within My form
O Guḍākeśa — conqueror of sleep (epithet of Arjuna)

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most magnificent statements in all of scripture: 'Behold the entire universe, with all moving and unmoving things, standing in one place — in My body.' In My body. Not alongside God. Not created by God and standing apart. In God's body. The entire cosmos — every galaxy, every atom, every laugh, every tear, every moment of joy and sorrow — is held within the divine body. And then, with extraordinary tenderness: 'and whatever else you wish to see.' God says: ask Me anything. The address 'guḍākeśa' — conqueror of sleep — reminds Arjuna who he is: the wakeful, alert, heroic soul capable of receiving this vision.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 7 contains the philosophical heart of the Vishvarūpa chapter: 'jagat kṛtsnam iha ekastham mama dehe' — the entire universe, in one place, in My body. This is the vision of Brahman as the sarvādhāra — the substratum of all. In Advaita Vedānta, Brahman is not just the cause of the world but the very substance of it, the way gold is the substance of all gold ornaments. The Vishvarūpa is not an allegory but an experiential truth: all of existence is one continuous divine reality. Note 'sacarācaram' — moving and unmoving — echoing the Īśā Upaniṣad's 'iśāvāsyam idam sarvam' — all this is pervaded by the Lord. Nothing is excluded from this divine body.
commentary.yogananda: In this extraordinary verse, Krishna reveals the ultimate metaphysical truth in experiential terms: the entire cosmos — every planet, every creature, every element, every force of nature — exists within the divine body. This is the mystical insight that great sages have expressed across traditions: the universe is the body of God. 'Sacarācaram' — moving and unmoving — covers the entire spectrum of existence, from the most dynamic forces of energy to the most inert forms of matter. All of it, in one place (ekastham), in the divine body. The phrase 'whatever else you wish to see' reveals Krishna's infinite generosity: nothing in existence is hidden from this vision.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the philosophical culmination of Krishna's invitation to the Vishvarūpa vision. 'Jagat kṛtsnam' — the entire universe without remainder — 'ekastham' — unified in one place — 'mama dehe' — in My body: these three phrases constitute the essence of the cosmic vision that follows. The Gita Press commentary emphasizes that 'mama dehe' refers to Krishna's transcendent divine body (divya deha), the Vishvarūpa, in which all existence inheres. 'Sacarācaram' (moving and unmoving) is a summary term for all categories of being, derived from the Vedic distinction between the animate (carā) and inanimate (acarā) dimensions of creation.

verses.sanskrit: न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा | दिव्यं ददामि ते चक्षुः पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् ||
verses.transliteration: na tu māṃ śakyase draṣṭum anenaiva svacakṣuṣā | divyaṃ dadāmi te cakṣuḥ paśya me yogam aiśvaram ||
verses.translation: But you are not able to behold Me with this ordinary eye of yours. I give you the divine eye — behold My lordly Yoga.

word_breakdown.meaning: I give / I grant (immediate present tense)
My lordly Yoga / My sovereign power of Yoga

commentary.dadaji: This verse contains one of the most generous acts in all scripture: 'I give you the divine eye.' Just like that. No elaborate ritual, no years of preparation. Krishna, out of pure love, instantaneously upgrades Arjuna's capacity to see. This tells us something profound about grace: it can arrive in a moment and completely transform what we are able to perceive. The ordinary eye (svacakṣu) can only see surfaces. The divine eye (divya cakṣu) sees the reality behind all surfaces. And notice: it is given. Arjuna did not earn it — it was given. This is the meaning of anugraha — grace. 'Paśya me yogam aiśvaram' — Behold My lordly Yoga — the entire creative power of God, revealed in one overwhelming vision.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 8 is theologically crucial. Krishna explicitly states: you cannot see this with your ordinary eye (svacakṣus). This rules out the Vishvarūpa being a physical spectacle visible to bystanders. The 'divine eye' (divya cakṣu) is the Vedantic term for the faculty of higher knowledge — the capacity to see Brahman directly. The Kena Upaniṣad says: 'That which the eye cannot see, by which the eye is seen — that alone, know as Brahman.' The ordinary eye sees only diversity; the divine eye sees the unity underlying all diversity. The instant conferring of divya cakṣu by Krishna is the Guru's transmission (shaktipāta) — a direct awakening of the disciple's higher faculty of perception.
commentary.yogananda: This verse reveals a crucial truth about spiritual vision: ordinary human perception, no matter how refined, cannot perceive the full reality of God. The physical eye and even the ordinary mind are too limited, too conditioned by the laws of space, time, and causation to comprehend the Infinite. So Krishna, the Divine Guru, does what no human teacher can: He directly grants the divine eye — the faculty of intuitive, superconscious perception. In the language of Kriyā Yoga, this corresponds to the awakening of the spiritual eye (the ājñā chakra, the single eye of which Christ spoke). The 'lordly Yoga' (yogam aiśvaram) is God's own infinite creative power, the divine līlā that sustains all of existence.
commentary.goyandka: The granting of the divine eye (divya cakṣu) in this verse is the pivotal event of Chapter 11. Krishna acknowledges the limitation of the ordinary human eye — it is calibrated for the phenomenal world and cannot perceive the transcendent cosmic form. The divine eye is a special faculty granted by Bhagavan's grace (prasāda) and represents the capacity for direct divine vision (sākṣātkār). This divine eye corresponds to the 'jñāna-cakṣu' (eye of wisdom) and 'yoga-cakṣu' mentioned in the Upaniṣads. 'Yogam aiśvaram' — the lordly Yoga — refers to the supernatural power (yoga-māyā) by which Krishna simultaneously upholds and pervades all of creation.

verses.sanskrit: एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजन्महायोगेश्वरो हरिः | दर्शयामास पार्थाय परमं रूपमैश्वरम् ||
verses.transliteration: evam uktvā tato rājan mahāyogeśvaro hariḥ | darśayām āsa pārthāya paramaṃ rūpam aiśvaram ||
verses.translation: Having thus spoken, O King, Hari, the great Lord of Yoga, then showed Partha His supreme, lordly Form.

word_breakdown.meaning: O King — Sañjaya addresses blind Dhṛtarāṣṭra
the great Lord of Yoga (mahā=great, yoga, īśvara=lord)
Hari — name of Viṣṇu-Krishna, the Remover of sins

commentary.dadaji: With verse 9 the narrator shifts — we hear Sañjaya's voice, reporting to the blind king Dhṛtarāṣṭra what happened on that field. This shift is itself poignant. Dhṛtarāṣṭra cannot see; he receives everything through Sañjaya's words. In a way, he represents all of us who were not present and must approach the divine vision through scripture, through a narrator's description. 'Hari, the great Lord of Yoga, showed Partha His supreme, lordly Form.' The name 'Hari' means the one who takes away — He removes sins, He removes suffering, He removes blindness. And the phrase 'darśayām āsa' — 'showed' — is in the perfect tense: a completed, definitive act. The revelation happened. It is done. It is real.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: With this verse, Sañjaya takes over the narration — a significant structural shift reminding us we are hearing a story within a story. Sañjaya has been granted divine vision by the sage Vyāsa to witness and transmit the events at Kurukṣetra; now he describes the supreme moment of the Vishvarūpa. The name 'Hari' is deeply significant: it derives from the root 'hṛ' (to take away) and signifies the one who removes the sins and sorrows of those who take refuge in Him. 'Mahāyogeśvara' — great Lord of Yoga — distinguishes Krishna from all other masters of yoga: He is the source and sovereign of all yogic power, not merely a practitioner. 'Paramaṃ rūpam aiśvaram' — the supreme lordly Form — confirms that what follows is a vision of absolute divine majesty.
commentary.yogananda: The narration shifts to Sañjaya, the spiritually gifted minister given divine sight by the sage Vyāsa to witness and transmit the events of the Kurukṣetra war to the blind king Dhṛtarāṣṭra. This transition reminds us that the Bhagavad Gītā is itself a kind of Vishvarūpa — a vision of divine truth transmitted through the medium of a gifted narrator to those who cannot be present. 'Hari, the great Lord of Yoga, showed Partha the supreme lordly Form.' The name Hari (the Remover) is perfect here: the vision Krishna reveals will remove Arjuna's last vestiges of personal self-centeredness. 'Mahāyogeśvara' indicates that what follows is not a natural occurrence but a sovereign divine act.
commentary.goyandka: The shift from dialogue to Sañjaya's narration marks the beginning of the actual Vishvarūpa revelation. Sañjaya, endowed with divine vision by Mahārṣi Vyāsa, serves as the intermediary between the cosmic event and the blind king Dhṛtarāṣṭra — and through him, to all of us. The name 'Hari' carries profound significance: in the Viṣṇu Sahasranāma, 'Hari' is the one who destroys sins and who is the color of new leaves — a reference to His cosmic creative vitality. 'Mahāyogeśvaraḥ' establishes Krishna's supreme authority: He is the very source of all yogic power. 'Darśayām āsa' — He showed — marks the actual conferring of the vision, the supreme divine gift.

verses.sanskrit: अनेकवक्त्रनयनमनेकाद्भुतदर्शनम् | अनेकदिव्याभरणं दिव्यानेकोद्यतायुधम् ||
verses.transliteration: anekavaktranetram anekādbhutadarśanam | anekadivyābharaṇaṃ divyānekodyatāyudham ||
verses.translation: A form with many faces and eyes, with many wondrous visions, with many divine ornaments, with many uplifted divine weapons.

commentary.dadaji: Sañjaya struggles to describe the indescribable. He can only say 'many, many, many' — many faces, many eyes, many ornaments, many weapons. Human language is built for describing single things, sequences, proportions. But the cosmic form has no single face — every face is His face. It has no one weapon — every force of power in the universe is His weapon. The divine ornaments suggest that this form is not merely terrifying but magnificent — adorned, glorious, resplendent. This is not a nightmare vision; it is the vision of reality itself in its full, unfiltered grandeur. When you see the ocean for the first time after living in a landlocked place all your life, you grasp at words. Sañjaya is in that condition, and the ocean he is describing is infinite.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 10 begins the breathtaking description of the Vishvarūpa that continues through verse 31. The description is structured as a series of 'aneka' (many) compounds, deliberately overwhelming the reader's capacity to form a single unified mental image. This is intentional: the cosmic form cannot be mentally grasped in the way a human form can be grasped. In Vedānta, Brahman is described as 'ananta' — infinite — and infinity, by definition, cannot be contained in a single mental image. The many faces suggest omniscience (awareness in all directions simultaneously); the many ornaments suggest infinite divine wealth and beauty; the many upraised weapons suggest absolute cosmic power.
commentary.yogananda: The description of the Vishvarūpa begins with multiplication — the relentless 'aneka,' meaning 'many,' 'not-one,' repeated again and again. Many faces: God looks out at creation from every conscious being simultaneously. Many eyes: God sees through every eye that has ever opened. Many divine ornaments: the beauty of the cosmos in all its forms — the colors of nebulae, the symmetry of crystals, the play of light on water — these are God's ornaments. Many uplifted weapons: the cosmic forces of transformation, creation, and dissolution that shape galaxies and atoms alike. The vision that Arjuna is now seeing is nothing less than the universe itself, seen from within, seen as alive, seen as One Being wearing infinite faces.
commentary.goyandka: This verse initiates Sañjaya's extended description of the Vishvarūpa (verses 10–14), characterized by the repeated use of 'aneka' (many) to convey the infinitude of the cosmic form. The 'many faces' indicate that the Vishvarūpa encompasses all directions of space simultaneously; the 'many eyes' indicate all-pervading consciousness; the 'divine ornaments' (divyābharaṇa) include traditional Vaiṣṇava symbols — the crown, the garland, the conch, the disc; the 'uplifted divine weapons' indicate the sovereign cosmic power that sustains, protects, and when necessary dissolves creation. This verse should be studied alongside the Puruṣa Sūkta (Rigveda 10.90) which similarly describes the cosmic Person with 'a thousand heads, a thousand eyes, a thousand feet.'

verses.sanskrit: दिव्यमाल्याम्बरधरं दिव्यगन्धानुलेपनम् | सर्वाश्चर्यमयं देवमनन्तं विश्वतोमुखम् ||
verses.transliteration: divyamālyāmbaradharaṃ divyagandhānulepanaṃ | sarvāścaryamayaṃ devam anantaṃ viśvatomukham ||
verses.translation: Wearing divine garlands and garments, anointed with divine fragrances — all-wonderful, divine, infinite, with faces everywhere.

commentary.dadaji: Sanjaya continues his description for the blind king Dhritarashtra, painting the cosmic form in its glorious aspect — divine garlands, divine fragrances, all-wonderful. The word 'viśvatomukha' — facing all directions — is perhaps the most important detail: God has no 'back.' There is no angle from which His face is not turned toward you. No matter where you stand, no matter what you have done or left undone, the cosmic face of the Divine is looking at you with the same infinite gaze. This is the ultimate reassurance of the Gita.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The description of the cosmic form as wearing divine ornaments reflects the Vedic understanding that the cosmos is not barren matter but is itself the self-expression of divine consciousness — decorated, vibrant, meaningful. The Taittiriya Upanishad speaks of 'ānandamaya' — the universe as bliss-made — and this verse touches that same truth. 'Viśvatomukha' — facing all directions — is a direct echo of the Isha Upanishad: 'Sa paryagāt' — 'He pervades in all directions.' The infinite faces of the cosmic form represent the omnidirectional awareness of Brahman, from which nothing is hidden or absent.
commentary.yogananda: In deep meditation, the cosmic form reveals itself as light — infinite, blazing, fragrant with spiritual joy. The divine garlands and fragrances are not imaginative embellishments but direct reports of subtle-plane perception: the higher planes of existence are genuinely more beautiful, more vibrant, more filled with divine qualities than what the physical senses can apprehend. 'Anantam viśvatomukham' — infinite, facing everywhere — describes the AUM: the primordial sound that pervades all space equally, from which all creation emanates in every direction simultaneously.
commentary.goyandka: Sanjaya's description of the cosmic form combines the majestic (divyamālya, divyagandhānulepana — divine garlands and fragrances) with the overwhelming (anantam viśvatomukha — infinite, omnidirectional). This dual nature reflects the dual response of the devotee before the Viśvarūpa: aesthetic delight in its beauty and existential awe at its infinity. The Purāṇas describe the viśvatomukha aspect as the Viśvarūpa's most characteristic feature — even the Vedic sacrificial post (yūpa) is called viśvatomukha because it symbolises the omnipresence of the sacrifice's ultimate recipient: Brahman Himself.

verses.sanskrit: दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता | यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः ||
verses.transliteration: divi sūryasahasrasya bhavet yugapad utthitā | yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syād bhāsas tasya mahātmanaḥ ||
verses.translation: If the radiance of a thousand suns were to blaze forth simultaneously in the sky — that might resemble the splendour of that great-souled One.

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most famous verses of the entire Gita — J. Robert Oppenheimer, witnessing the world's first nuclear test at Trinity in 1945, recalled this verse: 'Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.' The verse tells us that if a thousand suns blazed simultaneously, that is only perhaps what the radiance of the Lord might resemble — and even this is a simile, an approximation that falls infinitely short. What does this mean for us? It means that every moment we are in the presence of something whose splendour exceeds all possible human measurement. Yet this same infinite radiance knows your name, holds your hand, loves you.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The 'thousand suns' simile is the Vedic tradition's way of pointing toward the ineffable — the Kena Upanishad declares 'yad manasā na manute' — 'that which the mind cannot think' — and Sanjaya reaches for the largest possible image and then hedges it with 'sadṛśī sā syāt' — 'it might be similar.' The language of approximation is crucial: the conditional mood (bhavet, syāt) signals that even this cosmic image is acknowledged as inadequate. Brahman's light is self-luminous (svayamprakāśa) — it is the very precondition of all other light; a thousand suns are themselves illumined by It, not the other way around.
commentary.yogananda: In the highest states of samadhi, the meditator experiences light — an inner light more brilliant than the outer sun, yet perfectly peaceful and not blinding. This is the light that Arjuna is perceiving through the divine eye (divya cakṣu) that Krishna gave him. Paramahansa Yogananda wrote: 'When the spiritual eye opens, you behold the divine light as billions of suns.' The thousand-sun image is Sanjaya's honest attempt to describe something that transcends all physical analogy — and even his most extreme comparison falls short. Every atom of that light is conscious, blissful, and permeated with love.
commentary.goyandka: This verse (11.12) stands as one of the great poetic achievements of the Mahābhārata — the comparison of the Viśvarūpa's splendour to a thousand simultaneous suns is the most powerful cosmic image in all of Sanskrit literature. Sanjaya's grammar is carefully hedged: 'sā syāt' — 'it would be (merely similar)' — indicating that even this image cannot capture the full reality. The traditional commentators note that this verse should be read alongside the Puruṣa Sūkta: 'ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt' — 'Beyond darkness, of the colour of the sun' — both texts pointing to the same self-luminous Brahman that transcends all created luminosity. This is the verse to contemplate in moments of prayer: that the Being to whom you pray is more brilliant than ten billion suns, yet more intimate than your own heartbeat.

verses.sanskrit: तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा | अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा ||
verses.transliteration: tatraikasthaṃ jagat kṛtsnaṃ pravibhaktam anekadhā | apaśyad devadevasya śarīre pāṇḍavas tadā ||
verses.translation: Then the Pandava (Arjuna) saw the entire universe — divided in many ways — standing in one place in the body of the God of gods.

commentary.dadaji: This is the pinnacle of spiritual vision — seeing the entire universe in one place, in God's body. Not the universe as chaotic fragments scattered across space and time, but the universe as a unified whole, 'divided in many ways' yet fundamentally one. This is what the saints and sages experience in their deepest states: unity in the midst of multiplicity, God's body as the very substance of all that exists. You and I and the stars and the rivers are all parts of this same one body. What would it do to our relationships, our conflicts, our wars, if we genuinely saw this?
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is the experiential confirmation of the Vedantic mahāvākya 'sarvam khalv idam brahma' — all this is indeed Brahman. The Chandogya Upanishad teaches this as a verbal proposition; Chapter 11 of the Gita presents it as Arjuna's actual visual experience. 'Ekastham jagat kṛtsnam pravibhaktam anekadhā' — the universe as one (ekastha) yet diversified (pravibhakta anekadhā) — is the precise description of the Vedantic paradox: Brahman is one, undivided, yet the apparent multiplicity of the world arises from and within that one. The divine eye sees both the unity and the diversity without contradiction.
commentary.yogananda: The great mystics of all traditions have described this moment — the cosmic vision where the illusion of separation dissolves and the whole universe is seen as one living being. Meister Eckhart saw 'all things in God'; the Sufi poet Rumi wrote of the drop realising it is the ocean. Arjuna's experience here is the direct perceptual realisation of what the entire Gita has been teaching in words. 'Ekastham' — in one place — is the key: not distributed across space, but all simultaneously present in the eternal Now. This is what samadhi reveals: the spatial separation of the world is itself a kind of optical illusion of the individuated mind.
commentary.goyandka: Sanjaya's description reaches its summit in this verse — the entire universe (jagat kṛtsnam), though appearing differentiated in countless ways (pravibhaktam anekadhā), is seen as one (ekastham) in the body of the Supreme Lord. This is the vivid resolution of the philosophical question that the Gita poses from Chapter 1: what is the relationship between the individual, the world, and the Supreme? Here the answer is given visually: the world and all its contents are within the Lord, held in and by Him. Traditional commentators cite this verse to establish the Viśiṣṭādvaita teaching of sarvam viṣṇumayam — all is pervaded by Vishnu; the Advaita reads it as 'sarvam brahma' — all is the one undivided Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जयः | प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत ||
verses.transliteration: tataḥ sa vismayāviṣṭo hṛṣṭaromā dhanañjayaḥ | praṇamya śirasā devaṃ kṛtāñjalir abhāṣata ||
verses.translation: Then Dhananjaya (Arjuna), overwhelmed with amazement, with hair standing on end, bowed his head to the Lord and, with palms joined, spoke.

word_breakdown.meaning: with hair standing on end (goosebumps of awe)

commentary.dadaji: Before words, there is the body's response — hair standing on end, palms pressed together, head bowed. This is what genuine contact with the Divine does to a human being: it bypasses the rational mind and goes straight to the nervous system, straight to the heart. 'Hṛṣṭaromā' — the hair standing on end in awe — is the same response described in South Indian classical aesthetics as the highest aesthetic emotion, 'romāñca,' the sign that something transcendent has touched the human soul. Then Arjuna collects himself and speaks. Everything in this verse — the awe, the prostration, the joined palms — is a model for our own approach to prayer.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Sanjaya's description of Arjuna's physical state before he speaks — vismayāviṣṭa (overcome with wonder), hṛṣṭaromā (hair standing on end), praṇamya śirasā (bowed with his head), kṛtāñjaliḥ (palms joined) — encodes the complete posture of the ideal devotee. In the Vedantic tradition, this is the state of mumukṣutva (intense desire for liberation) combined with śraddhā (faith) and viveka (discrimination) — all three ignited simultaneously by direct perception of the Divine. The hair standing on end (romāñca or pulaka) is listed in the Bhakti literature as one of the aṣṭa-sātvika-bhāvas — the eight involuntary expressions of the highest devotional experience.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's response is the body speaking before the mind has recovered its composure. This is authentic spiritual experience — the organism recognises the Divine before the intellect can categorize and label it. The hair standing on end (hṛṣṭaromā) is a physiological marker of the awakening of spiritual energies — what the ancient texts call 'romāñca' and what modern science might associate with the activation of the parasympathetic nervous system in states of profound awe. Then, instinctively, the palms join and the head bows — the body already knows how to pray; the devotional intelligence of the body is deeper than the rational mind.
commentary.goyandka: This transitional verse is masterfully placed by Vyāsadeva — it captures the exact moment between vision and response, between what is seen and what can be said. Dhanañjaya — Arjuna by his epithet meaning 'winner of wealth' — here wins the greatest wealth of all: direct perception of the Lord's cosmic form. The physical signs (vismayāviṣṭa, hṛṣṭaromā) combined with the devotional posture (praṇamya, kṛtāñjaliḥ) represent the complete integration of outer form and inner experience in the act of worship. The subsequent hymn (v15-31) flows from this state of total surrender — not composed by the rational mind but arising spontaneously from a consciousness that has been overwhelmed by the Real.

verses.sanskrit: पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान् | ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थम् ऋषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान् ||
verses.transliteration: paśyāmi devāṃs tava deva dehe sarvāṃs tathā bhūtaviśeṣasaṅghān | brahmaṇam īśaṃ kamalāsanastham ṛṣīṃś ca sarvān uragāṃś ca divyān ||
verses.translation: I see all the gods in Your body, O God, and all the various hosts of beings; Brahma the Lord, seated on the lotus, all the sages, and the divine serpents.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's great hymn begins here — not with theology but with testimony: 'I see.' These are the words of direct experience, not inference or tradition. He sees Brahma on his lotus throne within Krishna's body. This means the creator of the universe is Himself contained within the Supreme. What Brahma creates — time, space, beings, worlds — all of it is held within Krishna. This is the hierarchy of the cosmos revealed in a single vision: the creator is within the Creator, the worshipped is within the Worshipped. Every time we pray, we are somehow touching the being who holds even Brahma in His body.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's vision maps precisely onto the Vedantic cosmological scheme: Brahma (the creator-principle, identified with hiraṇyagarbha — the cosmic golden egg), the sages (the ṛṣis who are the cosmic intelligence), and the divine serpents (the primal energies, nāga-śaktis) are all seen within the one Supreme. The Mundaka Upanishad describes Brahman as 'that from which all these beings take birth, by which they are sustained, and into which they dissolve' — Arjuna is experiencing this doctrine not as philosophy but as direct vision. The lotus-seated Brahma within Krishna's body is the specific Vedantic statement that saguṇa Brahman (Krishna) contains and transcends the creative principle (Brahma).
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna is describing the experience that the great clairvoyants and mystics have reported across all traditions — the perception of the inner worlds superimposed upon the physical world. Within the blazing cosmic form, he sees Brahma seated on the lotus: this lotus corresponds in yogic anatomy to the highest lotus of the crown chakra (sahasrāra), where the individual consciousness meets the cosmic. The divine serpents (uragān divyān) are the pranic energies that sustain all life — seen in their true nature as conscious, luminous, and divine. All of creation, properly seen, is a living temple.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's vision follows the traditional Purāṇic cosmological hierarchy: at the apex is Brahma, the prajāpati (lord of progeny and creation), seated on the lotus that grew from Viṣṇu's navel. Seeing Brahma within Krishna's body establishes the Vaiṣṇava theological principle that Brahma derives his creative power from Viṣṇu — he is the instrumental cause, while Viṣṇu-Krishna is the ultimate material and efficient cause. The divine serpents (uragān divyān) refer primarily to the great nāgas — Ananta, Vasuki, Takshaka — who are honoured in the Vedic tradition as guardians of cosmic energy and of the waters of life. This verse inaugurates Arjuna's personal testimony which constitutes one of the great hymns in Sanskrit devotional literature.

verses.sanskrit: अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम् | नान्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप ||
verses.transliteration: anekabāhūdaravaktranetram paśyāmi tvāṃ sarvato'nantarūpam | nāntaṃ na madhyaṃ na punas tavādim paśyāmi viśveśvara viśvarūpa ||
verses.translation: I see You on all sides with infinite form, with many arms, bellies, faces and eyes — I see no end, no middle, and no beginning to You, O Lord of the Universe, O Universal Form.

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna is trying to find the boundaries of the Cosmic Form and cannot — no beginning, no middle, no end. This is the experiential encounter with infinity. We use the word 'infinite' casually; Arjuna is actually experiencing it, and it is overwhelming. The repetition of 'na' — no beginning, no middle, no end — is like a mind reaching out in every direction and finding only more God. This is why the mystics say that in God's presence all seeking stops: you cannot find the edges of Something that has no edges. The appropriate response is simply to fall into this boundlessness and rest there.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The three negations — no end (antam), no middle (madhyam), no beginning (ādi) — precisely echo the Vedantic description of Brahman as 'anādi ananta' (beginningless and endless) and the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad's neti-neti method. But here it is not theological negation but experiential: Arjuna looks and cannot find a limit. The two addresses — 'viśveśvara' (Lord of the universe) and 'viśvarūpa' (the Universal Form itself) — point to the same reality from two angles: the Lord who governs the universe (the 'governing' principle) and the Lord who is the universe (the 'cosmic' principle). In Advaita terms, these are Brahman as niyantā (controller) and Brahman as the world itself — both ultimately one.
commentary.yogananda: The vision of the cosmic form that Arjuna is describing — many arms, faces, eyes, infinite on all sides — is not simply a larger human body; it is consciousness itself taking on perceivable attributes for Arjuna's understanding. In the highest superconsciousness, the meditator perceives the one Consciousness as simultaneously everywhere and nowhere, with no spatial boundaries or temporal limits. 'No beginning, no middle, no end' — this is the description of the Eternal Now, the present moment that contains all past and future within itself. To touch even a fragment of this in meditation is to be permanently changed.
commentary.goyandka: The verse's central theological content is carried by the three negations: na antam, na madhyam, na ādi — no end, no middle, no beginning. Traditional Vedāntic commentary (Śrīdhara, Madhusūdana Sarasvatī) notes that these three negations rule out all three types of limitation: spatial (no edge), temporal (no middle implies no timeline), and causal (no beginning). The dual epithet 'viśveśvara viśvarūpa' is especially beautiful — the Lord is simultaneously the ruler of the universe (viśveśvara, trans-cosmic) and the very form of the universe (viśvarūpa, immanent in all form). This is the Gita's most precise expression of the classical theological doctrine: parāpara-brahman, the Supreme who is both beyond and within all things.

verses.sanskrit: किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च तेजोराशिं सर्वतो दीप्तिमन्तम् | पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ताद्दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम् ||
verses.transliteration: kirīṭinaṃ gadinaṃ cakriṇaṃ ca tejorāśiṃ sarvato dīptimantam | paśyāmi tvāṃ durnirīkṣyaṃ samantād dīptānalārkadyutim aprameyam ||
verses.translation: I see You with crown, mace and discus — a mass of radiance shining everywhere, blazing on all sides like the light of fire and sun, immeasurable and hard to behold.

word_breakdown.meaning: difficult to look at/hard to behold

commentary.dadaji: The crown, mace and discus are the recognisable symbols of Vishnu — yet here they appear in cosmic proportions, blazing with the light of a thousand suns. 'Durnirīkṣyam' — hard to behold — is physically and spiritually accurate: the divine reality is not easy to look at directly, just as you cannot stare at the sun. The spiritual practice of contemplating God requires what the tradition calls 'antaḥ-cakṣu' — the inner eye — which has been especially opened for Arjuna in this moment. The word 'aprameyam' — immeasurable — is one of the great names of Vishnu in the Sahasranama, reminding us that the beloved form before which we bow is beyond all measurement.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Vishnu iconography (crown, mace, discus) appearing within the cosmic form establishes that the viśvarūpa is not something other than the personal Lord — it is the same Krishna, the same Vishnu, now revealed in His full cosmic extent. The fire-and-sun simile for the Lord's radiance recalls the Kaṭha Upanishad: 'na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ' — 'There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars' — because the Ātman's self-luminosity makes all physical light appear as secondary. 'Aprameyam' — immeasurable, beyond all pramāṇas (means of valid knowledge) — indicates that Brahman cannot be an object of measurement; It is the very ground in which all measurement occurs.
commentary.yogananda: The Sudarshana discus (cakra) of Vishnu in yogic interpretation represents the spinning wheel of time and karma — Vishnu controls time itself. The mace (gadā) represents the power of karma-yoga — the force of right action. The crown (kirīṭa) represents the supreme authority of consciousness over matter. Seeing all of these attributes blazing simultaneously in the cosmic form, Arjuna is perceiving the complete cosmic government — the entire machinery of creation, sustenance, and dissolution held in one hand. 'Durnirīkṣyam' — too brilliant to look at directly — is why all meditation traditions use an intermediary: a name, a form, a mantra — to approach the Infinite gradually.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's vision of Krishna bearing the kirīṭa (crown), gadā (mace), and cakra (discus) within the cosmic form is theologically significant — it establishes the identity of the Viśvarūpa with the personal deity Viṣṇu rather than with an abstract universal force. The commentator Madhusūdana Sarasvatī notes that these iconic symbols, familiar to all devotees, ground the overwhelming cosmic vision in the recognisable form of the beloved Lord. 'Tejorāśim' — a mass of radiance — echoes the ancient Vedic Puruṣa Sūkta: 'sahasrārcis' — of a thousand rays. 'Aprameyam' — immeasurable — is one of the thousand names of Viṣṇu in the Viṣṇu Sahasranāma, confirming that what Arjuna sees is none other than the Supreme Puruṣa of the Vedas.

verses.sanskrit: त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम् | त्वमव्ययः शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे ||
verses.transliteration: tvam akṣaraṃ paramaṃ veditavyam tvamasya viśvasya paraṃ nidhānam | tvam avyayaḥ śāśvatadharmagoptā sanātanas tvaṃ puruṣo mato me ||
verses.translation: You are the imperishable, the supreme to be known; You are the supreme repository of this universe; You are the eternal guardian of dharma; I consider You to be the eternal Person.

word_breakdown.meaning: to be known/the object of knowledge

commentary.dadaji: In the midst of the overwhelming cosmic vision, Arjuna finds the theological words — imperishable, supreme, repository, eternal guardian of dharma. 'Nidhānam' — the treasury, the ultimate refuge — is one of the most beautiful images: God as the place where everything is safely kept. Every precious thing in the universe — every act of love, every moment of beauty, every sincere prayer — is deposited in this treasury and never lost. 'Śāśvatadharmagoptā' — the eternal guardian of dharma — reassures us that the moral order of the universe is not an accident but is actively maintained by the very Lord we see in this vision.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The four epithets in this verse constitute a compressed Vedantic theology: akṣaram (imperishable — the Katha Upanishad's teaching on the imperishable Ātman), paramam nidhānam (supreme repository — the Mundaka's description of Brahman as the source and resting place of all), avyayaḥ (inexhaustible — the ground that cannot be diminished), and sanātanaḥ puruṣaḥ (the eternal Person — the Puruṣa Sūkta's cosmic Person). 'Veditavyam' — the supreme to be known — parallels the Bhagavad Gita's own statement in 15.15: 'vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyaḥ' — 'By all the Vedas I alone am to be known.' What all scripture is reaching toward is this very being that Arjuna now sees directly.
commentary.yogananda: The universe has a treasury — this is one of the great consolations of spiritual understanding. Nothing true, nothing beautiful, nothing loving is ever lost — it is all deposited in the cosmic consciousness that Arjuna here calls 'paramam nidhānam.' The saints teach that every sincere prayer, every moment of genuine love, every authentic spiritual aspiration is permanently recorded in the divine consciousness. The 'eternal guardian of dharma' is the cosmic moral law — not an external rule but the intrinsic nature of reality itself, maintained by the all-pervading consciousness. When dharma is transgressed, reality itself reacts — not as punishment from above but as the natural consequence of violating the law of one's own being.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's theology here converges on several key Upanishadic and Gita teachings simultaneously. 'Akṣaram paramam' echoes Bhagavad Gita 15.16-17 where the imperishable (akṣara) is distinguished from the mutable (kṣara) and the Supreme Person (uttama puruṣa) transcends both. 'Viśvasya paramam nidhānam' — the supreme repository of the universe — is the teaching of the Śvetāśvatara Upanishad: 'yo devānām prabhavaś codbhavaś ca' — 'He who is the origin and emergence of the gods.' 'Śāśvatadharmagoptā' — the eternal upholder of dharma — directly echoes the Gita's most famous promise: 'sambhavāmi yuge yuge' — 'I take birth from age to age' for the protection of dharma. Arjuna's hymn is thus a perfect summary of the Gita's own theology.

verses.sanskrit: अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य- मनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम् | पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम् ||
verses.transliteration: anādimadhyāntam anantavīryam anantabāhuṃ śaśisūryanetram | paśyāmi tvāṃ dīptahutāśavaktram sva tejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam ||
verses.translation: I behold You without beginning, middle or end, of infinite might, of infinite arms — with the moon and sun as Your eyes, the blazing fire as Your mouth — scorching this universe with Your own radiance.

word_breakdown.meaning: with moon and sun as eyes

commentary.dadaji: The moon and sun are God's eyes — one cooling and gentle, one fierce and illuminating. The divine gaze is both of these at once: the compassionate Moon-eye that soothes and the bright Sun-eye that illuminates and reveals. The blazing mouth as fire reminds us of the Vedic image of Agni as the mouth of the gods — when we offer food, our prayers go directly to the Source. 'Scorching the universe with His own radiance' — this is not destructive but purifying: the divine fire burns away impurity and illumines what is real. This is what genuine contact with the Divine does to the soul.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The sun and moon as the eyes of the cosmic being directly echoes the Puruṣa Sūkta: 'cakṣor sūryo ajāyata' — 'From His eye the sun was born.' Here the direction is reversed: the cosmic form sees the universe through the sun and moon, which are thus His organs of perception. The blazing mouth-as-fire connects to the Vedic understanding of vāk (speech/fire) — in the Rig Veda, Agni is the primordial word, the first utterance. 'Sva tejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam' — scorching the universe by His own radiance — is the teaching of Brahman as the self-luminous source of all heat, light, and energy: the Kaṭha Upanishad's 'tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti' — 'By His light all this shines.'
commentary.yogananda: The sun-eye and moon-eye of the cosmic form represent the two great cosmic energies: solar (piṅgalā/prāṇa) and lunar (iḍā/apāna) — the masculine and feminine, the activating and the receptive, the knowledge and the devotion. In the human body, the right eye is connected to the sun channel (piṅgalā) and the left to the moon channel (iḍā). The divine being literally sees through these cosmic luminaries — and when the meditator's piṅgalā and iḍā are balanced in deep meditation, they begin to see with something of this divine vision. The fire-mouth consuming the universe is the cosmic pralaya (dissolution) — not destruction but transformation, as fire transforms matter into energy.
commentary.goyandka: This verse elaborates the cosmic physiology of the Viśvarūpa: the sun and moon as the two eyes represent the day-and-night cycle by which the Lord oversees the temporal order of creation (kāla-cakra). The fire-mouth (dīptahutāśavaktra) connects to the Vedic concept of kālāgni — the fire of time that gradually consumes all beings and all epochs. 'Sva tejasā' — by His own self-luminous radiance — is the key Vedantic affirmation: unlike the sun and fire which depend on an external source, Brahman is self-luminous (svayamprakāśa), the light by whose reflection all other lights shine. The three anādi-madhya-anta negations repeat the emphasis of verse 16, reinforcing that the cosmic form transcends all temporal categories.

verses.sanskrit: द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वाः | दृष्ट्वाऽद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन् ||
verses.transliteration: dyāvāpṛthivyor idam antaram hi vyāptaṃ tvayaikena diśaś ca sarvāḥ | dṛṣṭvādbhutaṃ rūpam idaṃ tavograṃ lokatrayaṃ pravyathitaṃ mahātman ||
verses.translation: The space between heaven and earth and all the directions — all of this is pervaded by You alone; seeing this wondrous and terrible form of Yours, the three worlds are trembling, O great Soul.

word_breakdown.meaning: the three worlds (earth, heaven, and the netherworld)

commentary.dadaji: Heaven and earth, all directions — the entire space of existence — filled by God alone. This is not metaphor. The devotee who truly feels this cannot move through the world in an ordinary way. Every direction you look, God is already there. Every breath you take, you are breathing the presence of the One who fills all space. The 'trembling of the three worlds' reminds us that the encounter with true infinity is naturally awe-inspiring — even terrifying in its vastness. Yet the devotee addresses this cosmic being as 'mahātman' — great Soul — with love and intimacy. The most terrifying thing in the universe is also the most beloved.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Isha Upanishad opens: 'Isāvāsyam idam sarvam' — 'all this is pervaded by the Lord.' Arjuna's statement here — 'vyāptaṃ tvayaikena' — is its direct experiential confirmation: pervaded by You alone. The 'antaram' (space between heaven and earth) echoes the Chandogya Upanishad's description of ākāśa (space) as Brahman — 'ākāśo vai brahma' — and here Arjuna discovers that this infinite space is itself filled with the divine presence, leaving no room for a reality separate from God. The three worlds trembling (lokatrayaṃ pravyathitam) is not a description of divine cruelty but of the natural effect of the Infinite encountering the finite: everything relative trembles in the presence of the Absolute.
commentary.yogananda: Space itself is filled with divine consciousness — this is the supreme teaching of this verse. The void between the atoms, the emptiness between the stars — all of it is permeated by the divine presence. This is what the physicist calls 'quantum vacuum' and what the mystic calls 'the divine plenum' — the fullness (pūrṇam) that appears as emptiness to ordinary perception. In deep meditation, this 'fullness of space' becomes directly perceptible: the meditator ceases to experience space as empty and begins to perceive it as vibrating with consciousness. This is the first taste of viśvarūpa-darśana available to the sincere meditator.
commentary.goyandka: The Rig Vedic concept of 'antarikṣa' — the middle space between earth and heaven — is the domain of Vayu (wind) and Indra, the mediating cosmic forces. Here Arjuna declares that this entire intermediate space is pervaded by Krishna alone — not by any subordinate deity but by the Supreme Himself. This establishes the Gita's core ontological claim: the Lord is both transcendent (beyond all worlds) and immanent (filling all space between worlds). 'Mahātman' — O great Soul — is Arjuna's intimate epithet for the cosmic being whose vastness now fills his entire field of perception; it is a title of reverence that combines awe (at the cosmic scale) with love (for the personal Lord), perfectly capturing the mood of the entire Vishvarupa chapter.

verses.sanskrit: amī hi tvāṃ surasaṃghā viśanti kecid bhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti | svastīty uktvā maharṣisiddhasaṃghāḥ stuvanti tvāṃ stutibhiḥ puṣkalābhiḥ ||
verses.transliteration: amī hi tvāṃ sura-saṃghā viśanti kecit bhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti | svasti ity uktvā maharṣi-siddha-saṃghāḥ stuvanti tvāṃ stutibhiḥ puṣkalābhiḥ ||
verses.translation: Indeed these hosts of gods are entering into You; some in fear, with palms joined, are praising You; bands of great sages and perfected ones cry svasti (may it be well) and extol You with copious hymns.

word_breakdown.meaning: saying svasti / may it be well

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna witnesses something beautiful even within his growing fear — the gods and sages do not flee from this overwhelming form, they rush toward it, some trembling, some singing. This is a lesson for us too: when life feels crushing and incomprehensible, the wise response is not to run away but to fold our hands and say svasti — may all be well. Even in the face of what we cannot understand, we can praise. The perfected ones know that behind every terrifying appearance of the Divine, there is only grace.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse opens the stuti — the hymn of praise — that Arjuna will sustain through several verses even as fear overwhelms him. The Upaniṣads speak of the Divine as both the terrible (ghora) and the auspicious (śiva); here we see both responses simultaneously: some gods enter in fear (bhītāḥ), others fold their palms and sing. The cry of svasti — the primordial blessing — is itself an affirmation that Brahman, even in its most terrifying aspect, is ultimately welfare (kalyāṇa). Arjuna is beginning to discover the non-dual truth that the destroyer and the sustainer are one.
commentary.yogananda: As souls at the moment of cosmic dissolution return to the ocean of Spirit, so the divine hosts are seen flowing back into the one Source from which they emanated. Fear arises from the illusion of separateness; even the gods who tremble here have not yet fully realized their unity with the Cosmic Christ-consciousness. The siddhas who sing svasti have touched that realization — they know that what appears as terrible withdrawal is only the Infinite reclaiming Itself. Every great kriyā experience carries a whisper of this: the ego trembles, but the soul sings.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavān's cosmic form draws all the celestial beings toward it like iron to a magnet. The devas who enter in fear still enter — even their fear is a form of surrender. The maharṣis and siddhas who cry svasti and sing stutis are models of the proper attitude before the Viśvarūpa: complete reverence, abundant praise, and wholehearted acceptance of whatever the Divine wills. The term puṣkalābhiḥ — copious, overflowing — indicates that no words are sufficient to praise Bhagavān fully; yet the sages pour forth hymns in abundance as an act of devotion, not as a claim of completeness.

verses.sanskrit: rudrādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyā viśve'śvinau marutaś coṣmapāś ca | gandharvayakṣāsurasiddhasaṃghā vīkṣante tvāṃ vismitāś caiva sarve ||
verses.transliteration: rudrā ādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyāḥ viśve aśvinau marutaḥ ca uṣmapāḥ ca | gandharva-yakṣa-asura-siddha-saṃghāḥ vīkṣante tvāṃ vismitāḥ ca eva sarve ||
verses.translation: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Vishvedevas, the two Ashvins, the Maruts, the Ushma-pas (ancestors who consume steam), and the hosts of Gandharvas, Yakshas, Asuras, and Siddhas — all of them gaze upon You in amazement.

word_breakdown.meaning: the Sadhyas (a class of celestial beings)
the Ushma-pas, ancestors who consume vapor/steam

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna carefully names all the great orders of celestial beings — from the fierce Rudras to the gentle Ashvins, from the luminous Adityas to the demonic Asuras — and observes that every one of them, without exception, stands gazing in amazement. This is profound: even beings who are normally adversaries of one another — Asuras and Siddhas, demigods and Gandharvas — are united in this single moment of shared wonder. The Divine does not divide; in the presence of Bhagavān's fullness, all distinctions dissolve. When we are truly open to the Infinite, our own inner conflicts also still.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Vedic cosmology assembles itself here in a comprehensive catalogue: Rudras (forces of dissolution), Adityas (forces of light and cosmic order), Vasus (elemental substrata of existence), and the rest, up to the Asuras. This is not mere mythology — it is a symbolic map of all the forces, both auspicious and inauspicious, that constitute phenomenal existence. The Gītā's point is that all of these — including what we ordinarily call evil or demonic — are within Brahman. Vismitāḥ — astonishment — is the natural epistemological response when the limited mind confronts the Unlimited. As the Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad says, Brahman is that before which all words and minds turn back.
commentary.yogananda: The enumeration of divine orders here maps the entire hierarchy of creation — from the Rudras (cosmic forces of change) to the Asuras (souls still entangled in ego-darkness). Paramahansaji taught that every level of consciousness is represented in this cosmic form: the angels, the elementals, the awakened and the unawakened, all gazing upon the one Source. In meditation, when the meditator touches the deeper states of samādhi, something similar occurs within — all the inner beings, all the habitual forces and tendencies of the mind, suddenly stand still in awe. The entire inner universe pauses before the Self.
commentary.goyandka: This verse enumerates the principal categories of celestial and semi-celestial beings to make the point that none of them is excluded from the vision of the Viśvarūpa. The Uṣmapāḥ — the pitṛ ancestors who subsist on vapor (uṣma) — represent even the realm of the departed. Thus beings of all three lokas (heavens, earth, and lower realms) are present and transfixed. Vismitāḥ — struck with wonder — is the only possible response of any being, however exalted, to the direct vision of Bhagavān's complete cosmic manifestation. This universal amazement is itself a teaching: no created being can fully comprehend the Creator.

verses.sanskrit: rūpaṃ mahat te bahuvaktranetram mahābāho bahubāhūrupādam | bahūdaraṃ bahuradaṃṣṭrākarālaṃ dṛṣṭvā lokāḥ pravyathitās tathāham ||
verses.transliteration: rūpam mahat te bahu-vaktra-netram mahā-bāho bahu-bāhu-ūru-pādam | bahu-udaram bahu-daṃṣṭrā-karālam dṛṣṭvā lokāḥ pravyathitāḥ tathā aham ||
verses.translation: Seeing Your vast form with many faces and eyes, O mighty-armed, with many arms, thighs and feet, many bellies, and terrible with many tusks — the worlds are trembling, and so am I.

word_breakdown.meaning: and so am I, likewise I

commentary.dadaji: With tathāham — and so am I — Arjuna drops all pretense of being a warrior unmoved by fear. He joins the trembling worlds in their honesty. This is actually a mark of Arjuna's spiritual openness: he does not suppress his fear or pretend to bravado. The cosmic form with its innumerable limbs and mouths shows us that the Divine is not contained in any single shape — it is the shape of everything simultaneously. When a devotee truly begins to see this, the small self cannot help but tremble; it is the trembling of the finite before the Infinite.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The repetition of bahu — many — throughout this verse is deliberate and powerful: many faces, many arms, many thighs, many bellies, many tusks. The Vedāntic insight here is that the Cosmic Form is the totality of all particular forms. As the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad declares, this universe is verily Brahman — not that it contains Brahman, but that it is Brahman. The daṃṣṭrā (tusks) are the instrument of cosmic destruction; their fearfulness signals that preservation and dissolution are equally functions of the one Reality. Pravyathitāḥ — the worlds tremble — because finitude cannot easily accommodate the vision of the Infinite.
commentary.yogananda: The many faces and arms of the Cosmic Form are not mere poetic imagery — they represent the innumerable channels through which the one Cosmic Energy (prāṇa) flows into manifestation. Each belly is a universe being sustained; each tusk is a force of transformation that appears destructive from below but is creative from the perspective of the Whole. Paramahansaji wrote that this vision corresponds to the experience of the yogi in the highest states of samādhi, where the personal sense of body dissolves and one perceives oneself as the body of the cosmos. The trembling Arjuna feels is the ego's last resistance before dissolution.
commentary.goyandka: Bhagavān is called mahābāho — mighty-armed — here, which is usually an epithet of Arjuna himself. By addressing Bhagavān with this title, Arjuna implicitly acknowledges that all strength belongs to the Lord. The compound bahu-daṃṣṭrā-karālam (terrible with many fangs) is the first direct acknowledgment of the raudra — the dreadful — aspect of the Viśvarūpa. The entire created world trembles (pravyathitāḥ lokāḥ), and Arjuna aligns himself with this universal trembling. This is the appropriate response to the recognition of Bhagavān's sovereignty over all creation, including the forces of dissolution.

verses.sanskrit: nabhaḥspṛśaṃ dīptam anekavarṇaṃ vyāttānanaṃ dīptaviśālanetram | dṛṣṭvā hi tvāṃ pravyathitāntarātmā dhṛtiṃ na vindāmi śamaṃ ca viṣṇo ||
verses.transliteration: nabhaḥ-spṛśam dīptam aneka-varṇam vyātta-ānanam dīpta-viśāla-netram | dṛṣṭvā hi tvām pravyathita-antarātmā dhṛtim na vindāmi śamam ca viṣṇo ||
verses.translation: Touching the sky, blazing, of many colors, with gaping mouths and large flaming eyes — seeing You, my inner self trembles; I find neither steadiness nor peace, O Vishnu.

word_breakdown.meaning: touching the sky, reaching the heavens
the inner self, the inner soul
I do not find, I cannot obtain

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna says his antarātmā — his inner self — is trembling. This is deeper than physical fear; it is the disturbance of the soul itself. He cannot find dhṛti (steadiness) or śama (peace). And yet he is still speaking to Bhagavān — that sustained address is itself an act of love and faith even in the midst of terror. This teaches us something precious: we need not be serene to pray. We can bring our trembling, our confusion, our loss of equilibrium, directly to the Lord. The very inability to find peace is placed in the hands of the one who can give it.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Nabhaḥspṛśam — touching the sky — indicates that the Cosmic Form has no upper limit; it surpasses the highest heavens. The Taittirīya Upaniṣad describes Brahman as that from which all speech, together with the mind, returns unable to reach it. Arjuna is experiencing that epistemological limit viscerally: his inner self (antarātmā) is shaken at its foundations. Dhṛti and śama — steadiness and peace — are the very qualities that Vedānta says arise from Self-knowledge (ātma-jñāna). Arjuna's confession that he lacks them here shows that the vision of the Viśvarūpa, while sublime, is not yet the same as liberating Self-knowledge; that comes later in the Gītā.
commentary.yogananda: The form that touches the sky (nabhaḥspṛśam) is the form of Infinite Consciousness itself, which has no boundary above or below, no edge in any direction. The many colors (anekavarṇam) are the vibrational frequencies of AUM as they manifest in different planes of existence — what Paramahansaji called the multifaceted light of Spirit. The gaping mouths are the vortices of cosmic energy that consume and recycle all form. When a meditator enters deep states and feels this cosmic vastness opening around them, the small sense of personal identity (ego) trembles exactly as Arjuna describes — dhṛtim na vindāmi — no foothold remains.
commentary.goyandka: This verse intensifies the description from the previous: now the form blazes (dīptam), spans the cosmos (nabhaḥspṛśam), and is multi-colored (anekavarṇam), suggesting its presence in all states and dimensions of existence. The word viṣṇo — O Vishnu — is significant here: Viṣṇu means the All-pervading (from viś, to pervade). Even in his terror, Arjuna instinctively names Bhagavān by the name that describes His omnipresence. This is the beginning of surrender: the recognition that the Being whose form terrifies is the same Being who pervades all, including oneself. There is nowhere to flee, and so Arjuna can only ask for grace.

verses.sanskrit: daṃṣṭrākarālāni ca te mukhāni dṛṣṭvaiva kālānalasannibhāni | diśo na jāne na labhe ca śarma prasīda deveśa jagannivāsa ||
verses.transliteration: daṃṣṭrā-karālāni ca te mukhāni dṛṣṭvā eva kāla-anala-sannibhāni | diśaḥ na jāne na labhe ca śarma prasīda deva-īśa jagan-nivāsa ||
verses.translation: Seeing Your faces terrible with tusks, like the fires of cosmic dissolution — I do not know the directions, I find no shelter. Have mercy, O Lord of gods, O Abode of the universe.

word_breakdown.meaning: terrible/fearsome with tusks/fangs (daṃṣṭrā = tusk, karāla = terrible)
just upon seeing, merely by beholding
the fire of Time/cosmic dissolution (kāla = Time/Death, anala = fire)
I do not know, I am disoriented
I do not find, I do not obtain
have mercy, be gracious, be pleased
O Lord of gods (deva = god, īśa = lord)
O Abode of the universe (jagat = world, nivāsa = dwelling)

commentary.dadaji: Diśo na jāne — I do not know the directions. When we lose our bearings completely, when even the basic coordinates of our inner life dissolve, what remains? Only the plea: prasīda — be gracious. Arjuna's two closing epithets are profound: deveśa, Lord of all the gods, shows Bhagavān's supremacy over every power; jagannivāsa, Abode of the universe, shows that even this terrifying form is ultimately a home. The Universe itself dwells within Bhagavān. There is nowhere else to go — and so surrender becomes the only natural movement. Arjuna's terror is becoming the doorway to complete self-giving.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Kālānala — the fire of Time — is one of the most potent compounds in the entire Gītā. Kāla is both time and death; anala is the fire that leaves nothing unconsumed. The face of the Viśvarūpa is likened to this fire not to terrify but to reveal the deepest truth: time is the Brahman in its aspect of dissolution. The Kaṭha Upaniṣad places the inquiry into the nature of death at its very center; here Arjuna meets that inquiry face to face, literally. I do not know the directions (diśo na jāne) is the disorientation of the ego when the usual cognitive landmarks disappear. The only remaining orientation is toward Bhagavān: prasīda — be gracious.
commentary.yogananda: The fire of cosmic dissolution (kālānala) that Arjuna sees in the mouths of the Cosmic Form is the same energy that mystics call the dark night of the soul — the moment when all the ego's comfortable structures are consumed. Paramahansaji said that the true guru often appears in this terrifying aspect to the chela whose ego-attachments must be burned away. The plea prasīda — be merciful — is the most important word in this verse: it is the turning of the will away from self-reliance and toward divine grace. When we genuinely do not know the directions anymore, we are finally ready to be guided.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's disorientation — I do not know the directions (diśo na jāne) — is complete. The Viśvarūpa has overwhelmed all of Arjuna's cognitive and emotional faculties.
