Yet in this moment of total helplessness, he addresses Bhagavān with two supremely beautiful names: deveśa (Lord of all deities, the supreme authority) and jagannivāsa (the very abode and ground of the universe). This is the paradox of devotional surrender: the Being who terrifies is the only Being who can give shelter. Arjuna has arrived at the heart of bhakti — not comfort-seeking devotion, but the surrender of one who has nowhere else to turn.

verses.sanskrit: amī ca tvāṃ dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ sarve sahaivavanipālasaṃghaiḥ | bhīṣmo droṇaḥ sūtaputras tathāsau sahāsmadīyair api yodhamukhyaiḥ ||
verses.transliteration: amī ca tvām dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ sarve saha eva avani-pāla-saṃghaiḥ | bhīṣmaḥ droṇaḥ sūta-putraḥ tathā asau saha asmadīyaiḥ api yodha-mukhyaiḥ ||
verses.translation: All these sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the hosts of kings — Bhishma, Drona, and that son of a charioteer (Karna), along with our own chief warriors as well —

word_breakdown.meaning: the hosts of kings (avani = earth, pāla = protector/king)
Drona, the preceptor of martial arts
son of a charioteer — Karna (tathā asau = and that one yonder)
with our own, with those on our side

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna is now cataloguing the names of those he loves and those he opposes — and he is seeing all of them rushing into the same devouring mouth. Bhishma, his beloved grandsire. Drona, his teacher. Even our own warriors — his own people. This is the cruelest and most personal dimension of the vision: the Cosmic Form does not spare the beloved. It is precisely those we cannot bear to lose who are seen entering the terrible mouths. This is the divine mercy in its most hidden form: showing us that clinging to persons, however dear, cannot be our ultimate refuge.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Note that Arjuna identifies three specific enemies by name: Bhīṣma (the eldest, most revered), Droṇa (the guru, the teacher), and Sūtaputra Karṇa (mentioned with a hint of social contempt that even now clings to Arjuna). But then he adds — with startling honesty — saha asmadīyaiḥ, along with our own. His side too is being consumed. The vision of kāla (Time) is wholly impartial; it does not take sides on the battlefield of Kurukṣetra. This impartiality of the Cosmic Form is the expression of what the Upaniṣads call the equality of Brahman: He who sees all beings in the Self and the Self in all beings (Īśa Upaniṣad 6).
commentary.yogananda: When Arjuna names Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and Karṇa, and then immediately includes his own warriors, he has touched a spiritual truth: the cosmic dissolution makes no distinction between the righteous and the unrighteous, the beloved and the hated. All forms are equally impermanent, equally expressions of the one Energy that now reclaims them. Master said: Even those you love most dearly are only passing guests in the inn of this world. The vision of the Viśvarūpa is an experiential confirmation of what the greatest saints have always taught — non-attachment is not indifference, it is the recognition of the one Life in all lives.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's naming of the principal warriors of both sides serves a doctrinal purpose in the Gītā: it establishes that the cosmic dissolution he witnesses in the Viśvarūpa is, in miniature, the actual historical outcome of the Mahābhārata war. What Arjuna sees here is not merely a vision but a revelation of what has already been decreed by Kāla — divine Time. The inclusion of asmadīyaiḥ (our own warriors) shows that Arjuna's attachment to his own side has not yet been fully surrendered; he feels the loss of his warriors as more painful than the loss of opponents. This residual partiality is what the subsequent teaching of the Gītā will resolve.

verses.sanskrit: vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇā viśanti daṃṣṭrākarālāni bhayānakāni | kecid vilagnā daśanāntareṣu saṃdṛśyante cūrṇitair uttamāṅgaiḥ ||
verses.transliteration: vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇāḥ viśanti daṃṣṭrā-karālāni bhayānakāni | kecit vilagnāḥ daśana-antareṣu saṃdṛśyante cūrṇitaiḥ uttama-aṅgaiḥ ||
verses.translation: They rush into Your mouths, terrible with tusks and fearful to behold. Some are seen with their heads crushed, stuck in the gaps between the teeth.

word_breakdown.meaning: in the spaces/gaps between the teeth (daśana = tooth)

commentary.dadaji: This verse contains the most graphically terrifying image in the entire Viśvarūpa episode: warriors stuck between the teeth, their heads crushed. Vyāsa does not soften this. Why? Because the truth about mortality is not soft. The Gītā is unflinching about what Time does to the body, to the warrior, to the most powerful kings and preceptors. Yet simultaneously, Bhagavān has already told Arjuna in Chapter 2 that the Self cannot be cut or burned or crushed. What Arjuna sees being destroyed here are the bodies alone. The uttamāṅga — the head, the seat of intellect — being crushed is the image of ego-dissolution, the precondition for liberation.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The uttamāṅgaiḥ — literally the highest limb, meaning the head — being cūrṇita (ground to powder) between the divine teeth is a stark image of the crushing of ahaṃkāra, the ego. The Sanskrit philosophical tradition places the seat of individuation in the head (and specifically the intellect, buddhi). Its destruction between the jaws of Kāla is the death of the false self. From an Advaita perspective, what is destroyed here is precisely what was never real — the sense of a separate, individual existence. As Śaṅkarācārya comments on this section of the Gītā, the cosmic form is Brahman revealing what It always does: dissolve the apparent into the real.
commentary.yogananda: The image of beings stuck between the teeth with heads crushed is a vision of how most souls leave the cycle of rebirth — not through conscious liberation but through being ground by the law of karma and the mechanical forces of nature. The ones who enter the mouth completely (who have fully surrendered) are in a very different state from those who are stuck — clinging even at the last moment to their separate identity. In yoga, the complete surrender of the ego-self into divine consciousness is liberation (mokṣa); the partial surrender leaves residue (saṃskāra) that must be worked out in further lives. The choice, Master taught, is ours.
commentary.goyandka: The graphic detail of cūrṇitair uttamāṅgaiḥ — heads being crushed — drives home the absolute sovereignty of Kāla over all embodied beings, however mighty. Bhīṣma, who had the power to choose the moment of his own death; Droṇa, master of every weapon; Karṇa, the greatest archer — all are reduced to this. The message for the sādhaka is clear: no accumulation of worldly power, however great, can resist the jaws of Time. Only the one who has identified with the Timeless (ātman) is truly safe. This is why Bhagavān will tell Arjuna in the next verses: I am Time (kālo'smi). Arjuna is being shown not just a vision, but his ultimate teacher.

verses.sanskrit: yathā nadīnāṃ bahavo'mbuvegāḥ samudram evābhimukhā dravanti | tathā tavāmī naralokavīrā viśanti vaktrāṇy abhivijvalanti ||
verses.transliteration: yathā nadīnām bahavaḥ ambu-vegāḥ samudram eva abhimukhāḥ dravanti | tathā tava amī naraloka-vīrāḥ viśanti vaktrāṇi abhi-vijvalanti ||
verses.translation: As the many swift currents of rivers flow toward the ocean alone, so do these heroes of the world of men enter Your flaming mouths.

word_breakdown.meaning: swift currents/floods of water (ambu = water, vega = speed/current)
toward the ocean alone, into the ocean only
heroes/warriors of the world of men (naraloka = human world)

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most beautiful and heartbreaking similes in all of sacred literature. Rivers do not resist the ocean. They do not deliberate about whether to arrive. From the moment of their birth in some Himalayan glacier or monsoon cloud, they are already flowing toward that one destination — the ocean that will absorb them completely. Our lives are like this. Every moment, every action, every loss and gain, every love — all of it is moving us, whether we know it or not, toward the one Source. The warriors rushing into Bhagavān's mouth are not being destroyed; they are returning home. The flame of the divine mouth is the flame of reunion.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This river-to-ocean simile is, philosophically speaking, the most precise image in the Gītā for the relationship between jīva and Brahman. The Chāndogya Upaniṣad uses the same image: These rivers, the eastern and the western, flow to the sea; becoming the sea itself, they do not know they are separate rivers. Individual souls (jīvas) are like rivers — distinct in form, bearing different names, arising from different sources — yet each one flows inexorably toward the ocean of Brahman. The dissolution (pralaya) is not annihilation but homecoming. The flame of the divine mouth (abhivijvalanti) is the fire of ānanda — bliss — not of destruction.
commentary.yogananda: Of all the images in the Viśvarūpa passage, this one — rivers flowing to the ocean — is the most consoling even within the terrifying vision. Every great river has its own character, its own beauty, its own path through mountains and valleys. And yet, it is always the ocean in disguise, moving toward self-recognition. So too every soul, regardless of its path — the warrior, the sage, the sinner, the saint — is the divine ocean in a temporary riverine form, flowing home. This is the cosmic optimism at the heart of Vedānta: not a single drop of consciousness is ever lost. The flames of the divine mouth are the light of the Supreme Self recognizing Itself in all returning forms.
commentary.goyandka: The simile yathā nadīnāṃ ... samudram is perfect in its precision: rivers do not choose to reach the ocean — their very nature impels them. So too the warriors of the human world do not choose to enter the cosmic mouth — they are impelled by the law of kāla (Time) and their prārabdha karma. The word eva (alone, only) after samudram is important: there is only one ocean toward which all rivers flow. Similarly, there is only one ultimate destination for all beings — return to the Supreme. The abhivijvalanti (flaming) mouths are the consuming fire of divine grace (prasāda) that burns away all karmic residue at the moment of return. No karma survives contact with the Divine.

verses.sanskrit: yathā pradīptaṃ jvalanaṃ pataṃgā viśanti nāśāya samṛddhavegāḥ | tathaiva nāśāya viśanti lokās tavāpi vaktrāṇi samṛddhavegāḥ ||
verses.transliteration: yathā pradīptam jvalanam pataṃgāḥ viśanti nāśāya samṛddha-vegāḥ | tathā eva nāśāya viśanti lokāḥ tava api vaktrāṇi samṛddha-vegāḥ ||
verses.translation: As moths, with great speed, fly into a blazing fire to their destruction, so too do these creatures swiftly enter into Your mouths for their destruction.

word_breakdown.meaning: moths (literally those who fly/fall), insects drawn to flame
for destruction, to their death (nāśa = destruction, dative)
with great speed, with powerful velocity (samṛddha = complete/full, vega = speed)
so too, exactly in the same way
the creatures, the people, the beings of the worlds
Your also, into Yours as well

commentary.dadaji: The moth simile cuts even deeper than the river simile because of its element of fatal attraction. The moth is not pushed into the flame — it is drawn. It rushes toward its own destruction with full speed (samṛddhavegāḥ). This is the mystery of the soul's relationship with the Infinite: there is something in us that longs for our own dissolution into the Divine, that senses — however dimly — that our individual existence is a kind of exile and the flame of God is home. The Sufi poets called this the love that burns the lover. Our desires, our addictions, our loves — all of them are distorted forms of this original longing for the one Flame.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The two similes placed together — rivers to ocean (v28) and moths to flame (v29) — are philosophically complementary. The river simile emphasizes the inevitability and naturalness of return to Brahman; the moth simile emphasizes the attraction — the pull of the Infinite on the finite. The moth's destruction (nāśāya) when read through the lens of non-dualism is liberation, not annihilation. The Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad speaks of the Self as the one light of lights — the flame to which all individual flames of consciousness are irresistibly drawn. The speed (samṛddhavegāḥ) underscores that when the ego-shell is fully opened, the return to Source is not gradual but instantaneous.
commentary.yogananda: The moth-and-flame image is the most powerful in all mystical literature across traditions — found in Rūmī, in the Song of Songs, in the words of St. John of the Cross. In the Gītā it appears at the precise moment when the mystical vision is at its most overwhelming. The moth does not understand the fire; it only knows the unbearable attractiveness of the light. So too the soul, in its deepest nature, is attracted to the Divine Light with a force that overrides all rational calculation. Paramahansaji wrote: The soul, like the moth that seeks the flame, must dare to plunge — and in plunging, finds not death but its own blazing nature. The nāśa (destruction) is the destruction of the illusion of separateness only.
commentary.goyandka: The brilliance of this simile lies in the phrase samṛddhavegāḥ, used identically in both the protasis (the moths) and the apodosis (the humans) — with full, unbounded speed. This verbal echo is Vyāsa's way of making the structural parallelism complete: as above (in the natural world of moths), so below (in the world of human destiny). The word pradīptam (blazing, fully kindled) echoes the earlier descriptions of the Viśvarūpa's blazing mouths and eyes. What ordinary creatures flee from as a source of destruction is what the divine cosmic fire truly is: the most complete expression of Bhagavān's power. For the sādhaka, this is an instruction: do not flee from the demands of sādhana that feel destructive to the ego — rush into them.

verses.sanskrit: lelihyase grasamānaḥ samantāl lokān samagrān vadanair jvaladbhiḥ | tejobhir āpūrya jagat samagraṃ bhāsas tavogrāḥ pratapanti viṣṇo ||
verses.transliteration: lelihyase grasamānaḥ samantāt lokān samagrān vadanaiḥ jvaladbhiḥ | tejobhiḥ āpūrya jagat samagram bhāsaḥ tava ugrāḥ pratapanti viṣṇo ||
verses.translation: You lick up all the worlds on all sides with Your flaming mouths, devouring them; Your fierce rays fill the entire universe with radiance and scorch it, O Vishnu.

word_breakdown.meaning: You are licking (intensive form of lih, to lick — expressing repeated, relishing action)
from all sides, all around, in every direction
all the worlds, all the realms entirely (samagra = complete, entire)
with fiery rays, with luminous energies, with splendor (tejas = fire/radiance)
the entire universe, the whole world
are scorching, are blazing, are heating intensely

commentary.dadaji: Lelihyase — You are licking. The intensity of this word is startling. Not merely swallowing, not merely consuming — licking, tasting, relishing. The cosmic dissolution is not a grim mechanical process for Bhagavān; it is an expression of the same divine delight that pervades all creation. The ugra (fierce) rays of Bhagavān fill and scorch the entire universe — yet these same rays are the light by which we see. Tejas in Sanskrit means both fire and the light of wisdom. The scorching that Arjuna describes is, from a higher perspective, the burning away of ignorance. As Arjuna will soon hear: I am Time, the great destroyer. Time destroys only what obscures the eternal.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is the culmination of Arjuna's description of the terrifying aspect of the Viśvarūpa. Lelihyase — the intensive, frequentative form of the verb to lick — conveys a relishing, ongoing action, not a one-time event. Creation, sustenance, and dissolution are not three separate events but one continuous divine activity. The Upaniṣads describe Brahman as the one who eats all foods (annāda, Taittirīya 3.10); the mouths of the Cosmic Form are the same mouths of Brahman that the Upaniṣad describes. Bhāsas tavogrāḥ — Your fierce radiances — recall the Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad: From that blazing one, suns and fire and Soma arise. Bhagavān's scorching is the scorching of a supreme intelligence that consumes all that is unreal.
commentary.yogananda: The simultaneous devouring (grasamānaḥ) and illuminating (bhāsaḥ) in this closing verse reveals the two aspects of the one cosmic AUM: the creative vibration that sustains (which fills the universe with light) and the dissolving vibration that reclaims (which scorches and consumes). Paramahansaji described cosmic dissolution as AUM withdrawing its sustaining frequency from each plane of existence in sequence — the very tejas (radiance) that was creation's light becomes the flame of dissolution. This is not tragedy; it is the in-breath of God after a cosmic out-breath. The entire Viśvarūpa chapter is Arjuna's experiential confrontation with that in-breath, and his growing readiness to surrender to it completely.
commentary.goyandka: Lelihyase and grasamānaḥ together — licking and devouring simultaneously — present the most intense image of Bhagavān's cosmic activity in this chapter. Yet even here, Arjuna addresses Bhagavān as Viṣṇo — the All-pervading — not as the destroyer alone. This is deeply significant: the very Being who devours and scorches is the same one who pervades all with His presence. The tejas (fiery energy) that burns is also the tejas that illumines. In the tradition of the Gītā-bhāṣya, this verse serves as the transition point: having shown Arjuna the totality of His cosmic action — creation, sustenance, and dissolution all active simultaneously — Bhagavān will now, in the next verse, speak for Himself and declare His true identity as Kāla, Time itself.

verses.sanskrit:
ākhyāhi me ko bhavān ugrarūpo namo'stu te devavara prasīda |
vijñātum icchāmi bhavantam ādyam na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim ||
verses.transliteration:
ākhyāhi me ko bhavān ugrarūpo namo'stu te devavara prasīda |
vijñātum icchāmi bhavantam ādyam na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim ||
verses.translation: Tell me who You are, so fierce in form. I bow to You, O best of gods — have mercy. I desire to know You, the Primal One. For I do not comprehend Your working.

word_breakdown.meaning: may there be salutation, I bow

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's question here is the most human question ever asked before God — "Who are You, really?" He has seen the cosmic form and is awed, even terrified, yet the heart within him still reaches out in love: "Have mercy, prasīda." This is the mark of a true devotee — not fleeing from God's vastness but leaning into it with folded hands. Arjuna does not pretend to understand. He admits openly: "I do not comprehend Your working." That honesty, that humble not-knowing, is itself a form of surrender. When we stop pretending we have God figured out, true knowledge can begin.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 31 marks the pivot from Arjuna as awe-struck witness to Arjuna as earnest seeker. The word "vijñātum" is significant — it is not mere jñāna (intellectual knowing) but vijñāna, the experiential, direct understanding spoken of in verse 7.2. Arjuna intuits that this cosmic form conceals as much as it reveals. The phrase "tava pravṛttim" — Your working or purpose — echoes the Kenopaniṣad's refrain: "That which is not thought by the mind, by which alone the mind thinks — know that alone as Brahman." The deepest reality cannot be grasped by ordinary cognition; Arjuna is right to confess he does not comprehend it.
commentary.yogananda: Standing before the infinite, Arjuna voices what every sincere meditator eventually experiences: the encounter with a dimension of existence so vast and incomprehensible that the ordinary mind trembles. "Who are You?" is not merely a biographical question — it is the soul's cry to the Absolute. Krishna's fierce cosmic form represents the universal life-force in its totality: creative, sustaining, and dissolving at once. The devotee who sincerely asks "Who are You?" with an open and stilled mind is already on the threshold of the answer. The request "prasīda — be gracious" is the prayer of the meditator: "Let Your grace still my restless mind so that I may perceive You directly."
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna addresses the Lord as "devavara" — best among the gods — and bows with the words "namo'stu te," demonstrating that even in bewilderment, reverence is the first response. The admission "na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim" — I do not understand Your purpose — is not weakness; the scriptures affirm that the ways of the Lord transcend human comprehension (Gītā 10.40). By humbly acknowledging his ignorance and begging for grace, Arjuna places himself in the proper disposition to receive the Lord's supreme disclosure in the very next verse. This is the teaching: true inquiry must be preceded by humility and devotion.

verses.sanskrit:
kālo'smi lokakṣayakṛt pravṛddho lokān samāhartum iha pravṛttaḥ |
ṛte'pi tvāṃ na bhaviṣyanti sarve ye'vasthitāḥ pratyanīkeṣu yodhāḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
kālaḥ asmi lokakṣayakṛt pravṛddhaḥ lokān samāhartum iha pravṛttaḥ |
ṛte api tvām na bhaviṣyanti sarve ye avasthitāḥ pratyanīkeṣu yodhāḥ ||
verses.translation: I am Time (kāla), the great destroyer of worlds, come to consume the worlds here. Even without you, all the warriors standing arrayed in the opposing armies shall cease to exist.

word_breakdown.meaning: I am Time / I am Death
destroyer of worlds, maker of world-dissolution
to gather up / consume the worlds
shall not be / shall not survive

commentary.dadaji: This is perhaps the most thunderous declaration in all of scripture: "I am Time — kālo'smi." When J. Robert Oppenheimer witnessed the first atomic bomb explode at the Trinity test in 1945, these were the words that came to his mind. He had read the Gita in Sanskrit and in that blinding flash of annihilation he recognized what Arjuna saw — a power beyond human agency, consuming everything. The Lord is telling Arjuna something both terrifying and, ultimately, liberating: the outcome is not in your hands. The warriors are already slain — "ṛte'pi tvām," even without you. Arjuna's participation or non-participation changes nothing at the cosmic level. So put down the weight of the world's fate, dear one — it was never yours to carry.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Kāla in Sanskrit carries dual meanings that are inseparable: Time and Death. The Lord is not merely personifying chronological time; He is declaring Himself to be the very principle by which all compounded things dissolve back into the Absolute. Śaṅkarācārya notes that "pravṛddha" — fully grown, all-pervading — indicates that this kāla is not a localized event but the universal law of impermanence itself. The statement "na bhaviṣyanti" — they shall not be — is in the future tense, yet the decision is already made. This points to a subtle Vedantic teaching: in the realm of the Absolute (paramārtha), outcomes that appear future from the empirical standpoint (vyavahāra) are already accomplished. Arjuna is being invited to shift his vantage point from the temporal to the eternal.
commentary.yogananda: When Krishna says "kālo'smi" — I am Time — He reveals the deepest cosmic truth: the very force that measures and ends all things is God Himself. Mystics across traditions have glimpsed this: Rumi's "What is not God is nothing"; the Christian "Alpha and Omega." In meditation, when one penetrates beyond the surface of experience into pure awareness, one encounters this same borderless, timeless presence that simultaneously contains and dissolves all forms. Oppenheimer's recollection of this verse at the Trinity atomic test is historically poignant — he recognized in that annihilating flash the same cosmic dissolution Arjuna witnessed on Kurukshetra. The verse also contains deep consolation: if God is the doer of all, then the individual soul is released from the crushing burden of ultimate authorship.
commentary.goyandka: The Gītā Press commentators note that this verse contains one of the most direct self-revelations of the Lord in the entire scripture. "Kālaḥ" here is not ordinary sequential time but Mahākāla — the Great Time that encompasses all cycles of creation and dissolution spoken of in the scriptures (Gītā 8.17–19). The Lord's statement "ṛte'pi tvāṃ na bhaviṣyanti" — even without you these shall not be — is not fatalism but a revelation of divine sovereignty. Bhīṣma, Droṇa, Karṇa — their span of life in this cycle is already exhausted by cosmic law. Arjuna's duty is clear: act as the Lord's instrument, neither inflated by the idea of being the victor nor paralyzed by guilt about the slain. This is the eternal dharmic teaching on action without false ownership.

verses.sanskrit:
tasmāt tvam uttiṣṭha yaśo labhasva jitvā śatrūn bhuṅkṣva rājyaṃ samṛddham |
mayaivaite nihatāḥ pūrvam eva nimittamātraṃ bhava savyasācin ||
verses.transliteration:
tasmāt tvam uttiṣṭha yaśaḥ labhasva jitvā śatrūn bhuṅkṣva rājyam samṛddham |
mayā eva ete nihatāḥ pūrvam eva nimittamātram bhava savyasācin ||
verses.translation: Therefore arise and win glory. Having conquered enemies, enjoy a prosperous kingdom. By Me alone are these already slain — be merely the instrument (nimitta), O Savyasachin\!

word_breakdown.meaning: merely the instrument, only the secondary cause
O Savyasāchin — ambidextrous archer, name of Arjuna

commentary.dadaji: The word that strikes like lightning in this verse is "nimittamātram" — merely the instrument. This single word dissolves the entire weight of ego-driven action. Arjuna has been agonizing, "If I fight, I am the killer of my kin." But Krishna says: you are not the doer — I am. You are the bow, I am the archer. The carpenter's chisel does not take credit for the sculpture. Once we truly absorb this — that we are instruments of a will infinitely greater than our own — action becomes effortless, fearless, and free of the dread of sin. The Lord calls Arjuna "savyasācin" — one equally skilled with both hands — reminding him of his unique gifts. God has already placed in each of us the specific abilities for our particular role. Rise and use them.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Nimittamātram — "merely the instrument" — is one of the most philosophically charged compound words in the Gita. In Sanskrit philosophical analysis, a nimitta-kāraṇa is the instrumental or efficient cause, as distinguished from the upādāna-kāraṇa, the material cause. By saying Arjuna is only the nimittamātra, Krishna places all aspects of causation within Himself — He is the material, the efficient, and the ultimate identity of all action. This verse is the practical application of the Sāṃkhya-Yoga synthesis Krishna began in chapter two. The Brahmasūtra (2.1.34) similarly affirms that Brahman alone is the sole cause — the individual is the occasion, not the originator.
commentary.yogananda: The divine command "uttiṣṭha" — arise — rings through the ages. It is the call not merely to physical action on a battlefield but to the awakening of the soul from the sleep of ego-identification. When we realize we are not the doers but instruments of the Infinite — "nimittamātram bhava" — life transforms. Every action becomes worship, every effort an offering. Sri Ramakrishna would say: "The wind blows — God's breath. The ocean waves — God's play. Let God's power move through you as wind moves through a hollow bamboo flute, and the result will be music, not noise." Arjuna is being asked to become that hollow flute — empty of ego, resonant with the Divine.
commentary.goyandka: The Gītā Press commentary emphasizes that "pūrvam eva" — already, beforehand — reveals that the Lord's will operates beyond the domain of human time. The slaying of Bhishma and others was pre-determined by the divine order. Arjuna's role as "nimittamātra" does not diminish him; it elevates him — he is chosen by God as the instrument of dharma's restoration. The address "savyasācin" is purposeful: it recalls Arjuna's greatest skill, reminding him that he is uniquely fitted for this task. The combination of "uttiṣṭha" (arise) and "bhuṅkṣva rājyam" (enjoy the kingdom) shows that the Lord's command includes both effort and its rightful fruit — dharmic action is never without its proper result.

verses.sanskrit:
droṇaṃ ca bhīṣmaṃ ca jayadrathaṃ ca karṇaṃ tathānyān api yodhavīrān |
mayā hatāṃs tvaṃ jahi mā vyathiṣṭhā yudhyasva jetāsi raṇe sapatnān ||
verses.transliteration:
droṇam ca bhīṣmam ca jayadratham ca karṇam tathā anyān api yodhavīrān |
mayā hatān tvam jahi mā vyathiṣṭhāḥ yudhyasva jetāsi raṇe sapatnān ||
verses.translation: Drona and Bhishma and Jayadratha and Karna and other brave warriors — already slain by Me — do slay them; do not waver. Fight\! You shall conquer the enemies in battle.

word_breakdown.meaning: slain by Me, killed by Me
do not waver, do not be troubled/distressed
you shall conquer, you will be victorious

commentary.dadaji: Krishna names them one by one — Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna. These are not abstractions; these are Arjuna's beloved teacher, his grandsire, his adversaries whom he respects. The Lord does not gloss over the weight of these relationships. And yet He says: "mayā hatān" — they are already slain by Me. The direct command "mā vyathiṣṭhāḥ" — do not waver, do not be troubled — is a command born of compassion, not harshness. Grief and hesitation are natural; God acknowledges them. But He also invites us past them into action aligned with the eternal order. "Jetāsi" — you shall conquer — is spoken in full certainty. When we act as instruments of the divine will, the result is guaranteed not by our power but by His.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The naming of Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, and Karna is significant from the standpoint of Arjuna's original crisis in chapter one. His paralysis arose precisely because of his deep bonds with these individuals (1.26–28). The Lord now addresses that specific grief directly — naming the very people Arjuna feared to slay, and declaring them already claimed by the divine will. The prohibition "mā vyathiṣṭhāḥ" uses the verb "vyath" — to be agitated, pained, anxious — the same root of distress that opened the Gita's philosophical dialogue. The entire Gita is thus framed between Arjuna's initial vyathā and this divine instruction to transcend it. The assurance "jetāsi" is the fruit of nimitta-bhāva: when the ego's claim to doership is surrendered, victory follows as a natural consequence.
commentary.yogananda: These are the four pillars of the Kaurava war effort: the guru Drona (representing attachment to the teacher-disciple bond), Bhishma (attachment to family loyalty and tradition), Jayadratha (the subtle obstructions on the path), and Karna (the rival ego, the shadow self). At a deeper symbolic level, Krishna is telling every spiritual seeker: the obstacles you fear most on your inner battlefield — the ingrained habits, the ancestral patterns, the rivals for your own highest nature — these too are "already slain" in the awareness of the Infinite. Your task is not to destroy them through your own force but to act with divine alignment, and the inner victory reveals itself. "Mā vyathiṣṭhāḥ" — do not be troubled — is the master's assurance to the sincere disciple.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Kṛṣṇa specifically names Droṇa, Bhīṣma, Jayadratha, and Karṇa because these four represent the greatest apparent obstacles to Arjuna's victory and the deepest sources of his emotional conflict. By declaring "mayā hatān" — slain by Me — before Arjuna has lifted a finger, the Lord reveals the nature of divine omniscience: outcomes within the temporal order are already known and willed by the Supreme. The words "yudhyasva jetāsi raṇe sapatnān" — fight, you shall conquer the enemies in battle — are direct, vigorous, and unambiguous. The Gītā does not advocate passive quietism; it commands righteous action, undertaken with the understanding that the Lord's will sustains the righteous warrior. Arjuna is called to fight not out of anger or ambition but as a sacred duty aligned with cosmic order.

verses.sanskrit:
etac chrutvā vacanaṃ keśavasya kṛtāñjalir vepamānaḥ kirīṭī |
namaskṛtvā bhūya evāha kṛṣṇaṃ sagadgadaṃ bhītabhītaḥ praṇamya ||
verses.transliteration:
etat śrutvā vacanam keśavasya kṛtāñjaliḥ vepamānaḥ kirīṭī |
namaskṛtvā bhūyaḥ eva āha kṛṣṇam sagadgadam bhītabhītaḥ praṇamya ||
verses.translation: Having heard this speech of Keshava, the diademed Arjuna, with trembling joined palms, bowing down again, with choked voice, deeply frightened, spoke thus to Krishna.

word_breakdown.meaning: of Keshava (Krishna, destroyer of the demon Keshi)
the diademed one, Arjuna (wearing the crown)
with choked/faltering voice, with emotion-broken speech
deeply frightened, overwhelmed with fear (reduplicated for intensity)

commentary.dadaji: Sañjaya pauses to describe what he sees through Vyāsa's divine gift: Arjuna trembling, palms joined, voice broken with emotion. The reduplication "bhītabhītaḥ" — deeply, utterly frightened — captures the totality of Arjuna's awe. Yet even in this state, he does not run. He bows. He speaks. This is the portrait of true devotion — not the absence of fear before the Infinite, but the courage to remain present and offer one's words even through a choked throat. The great hymn that follows in verses 36–46 pours forth not from a composed scholar but from a trembling human heart. That is what makes it so beautiful and so true.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Sañjaya's narration resumes with this verse, providing a visual and emotional transition between Krishna's thunderous declaration and Arjuna's great hymn of praise. The epithet "kirīṭī" — the diademed, crown-wearing one — is ironic and poignant: Arjuna who wears the crown of a great warrior is reduced to trembling like a frightened child before the cosmic form. "Sagadgadam" — speech broken by emotion — appears also in descriptions of the highest states of bhakti in the Bhāgavatam; it is not a mark of weakness but of the overwhelming power of divine encounter. "Namaskṛtvā bhūyaḥ" — bowing again — shows that each encounter with the divine revelation deepens rather than exhausts the impulse toward reverence.
commentary.yogananda: This transition verse is Sañjaya's gift to the listener — a moment of stillness between Krishna's cosmic declaration and Arjuna's ascending hymn. The detail "vepamānaḥ" — trembling — is spiritually precise. In deep meditation and in spontaneous encounters with the Divine, the physical body often trembles as it receives energies and realizations beyond its ordinary threshold. The saints have reported this: Ramakrishna would tremble and lose external consciousness in samādhi; Teresa of Ávila described inner trembling in her deepest prayer. Arjuna's trembling body and broken voice are the signs of a genuine theophany — a real, unmediated encounter with the Absolute in its totality.
commentary.goyandka: This verse, spoken by Sañjaya, serves as the introduction to Arjuna's mahāstuti — his great hymn of praise spanning verses 36 to 46. The Gītā Press commentators note that "bhītabhītaḥ" uses dvandva repetition for emphasis, indicating an extreme degree of awe-induced fear distinct from ordinary fear. This is the experience of the holy dread before the wholly Other. "Kṛtāñjaliḥ" with joined palms and "praṇamya" full prostration together show the complete physical expression of surrender. Arjuna's subsequent hymn arises from this ground of total prostration — it is not theological reasoning but the outpouring of a soul in the presence of the Supreme.

verses.sanskrit:
sthāne hṛṣīkeśa tava prakīrtyā jagat prahṛṣyaty anurajyate ca |
rakṣāṃsi bhītāni diśo dravanti sarve namasyanti ca siddhasaṃghāḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
sthāne hṛṣīkeśa tava prakīrtyā jagat prahṛṣyati anurajyate ca |
rakṣāṃsi bhītāni diśaḥ dravanti sarve namasyanti ca siddhasaṃghāḥ ||
verses.translation: It is right, O Hrishikesha, that the world delights and rejoices in Your glory; the terrified demons flee in all directions, and all the bands of Siddhas bow to You.

word_breakdown.meaning: rightly so, it is fitting, it is proper
O Hrishikesha — master of the senses, name of Krishna
by Your glory, by Your praise/renown
is attached with love, is enamored, is delighted
bands of Siddhas (perfected beings, accomplished ones)

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna opens his great hymn with an observation of exquisite balance: the same cosmic form that terrifies the demons fills the world and the perfected ones with joy. "Sthāne" — it is right, it is fitting. This word carries quiet wisdom: of course the universe rejoices in God's glory. Of course the demonic tendencies flee. Of course the siddhas bow. Everything is exactly as it should be. This is the beginning of real surrender — not fighting the nature of reality but recognizing its rightness. The same truth that destroys falsehood is the very truth that nourishes all genuine being. The devotee's heart, like the world, is "anurajyate" — drawn toward the Lord with love, not just awe.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The verse presents a cosmological polarity central to Vedantic metaphysics: those oriented toward the Real (siddhas — the accomplished ones) bow; those oriented toward the unreal (rakṣāṃsi — forces of obstruction and ego-assertion) flee in terror. The Lord's glory operates as a universal discriminator: it does not change, but it reveals the orientation of every being before it. The name "hṛṣīkeśa" — master of the senses — is particularly apt here: the Lord who governs all senses governs all of reality, and this governance simultaneously delights the wise and frightens those who resist it. "Anurajyate" suggests not mere happiness but a deepening attachment of love — the world falls in love with God's glory.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna observes the entire cosmos responding to the divine revelation as a living, feeling whole. The universe is not inert matter — it is consciousness at every level, and each level responds according to its nature to the presence of the Supreme Consciousness. The siddhas — those who have purified their inner instruments through sādhana — respond with namaskāra (reverence and recognition). The rakshasas — symbolic of the ego-forces, the tamasic and rajasic patterns — flee because they cannot bear the light of the Absolute. In meditation, the same process occurs inwardly: as divine awareness deepens, the ego-constructs scatter, and the purified aspects of the mind naturally bow in recognition and joy.
commentary.goyandka: The word "sthāne" at the beginning of Arjuna's hymn is the mark of a discerning and now illumined student. He no longer merely questions or fears — he affirms the rightness of all he has witnessed. The Gītā Press commentary notes that this affirmation is itself a form of surrender (praṇipāta) — agreeing that God's ways are proper and just. The response of the cosmos confirms the divine reality Arjuna has witnessed: the siddhasaṃghāḥ — the perfected ones in higher realms — who possess greater spiritual perception are depicted as already bowing, validating Arjuna's experience. The fleeing of the rakṣāṃsi illustrates the principle that the divine presence naturally dispels the forces of adharma.

verses.sanskrit:
kasmāc ca te na nameran mahātman garīyase brahmaṇo'py ādikartre |
ananta deveśa jagannivāsa tvam akṣaraṃ sat ca asat ca yat param ||
verses.transliteration:
kasmāt ca te na nameran mahātman garīyase brahmaṇaḥ api ādikartre |
ananta deveśa jagannivāsa tvam akṣaram sat ca asat ca yat param ||
verses.translation: And why should they not bow to You, O great Soul, who are greater even than Brahma and the original Creator? O Infinite, O Lord of gods, O Abode of the universe — You are the imperishable, the existent and the non-existent, and what is beyond both.

word_breakdown.meaning: O great Soul, O mighty Self
the original Creator, the first Cause
and what is beyond (both), the transcendent

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's question "kasmān na nameran" — why should they not bow — is a rhetorical affirmation blooming into theology. He has moved from trembling fear to clear-eyed recognition: You are beyond even Brahma, the greatest of the gods. You are "ādikartre" — the original Cause, the first Maker. And then comes the stunning philosophical climax: "tvam akṣaraṃ sat ca asat ca yat param" — You are the imperishable, You are existence, You are non-existence, and You are what is beyond both. This is not poetry alone — it is the map of ultimate reality. Brahman is sat (being), Brahman is asat (the void before manifestation), and Brahman is param — that which transcends even these categories. The heart that knows this has no more fear.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse reaches the philosophical summit of Arjuna's hymn. "Sat ca asat ca yat param" — the existent, the non-existent, and what is beyond both — directly echoes the Taittirīya Upaniṣad and the Nāsadīya Sūkta's inquiry into what lay before even non-existence. Śaṅkara explains that "sat" refers to the manifest (vyakta), "asat" to the unmanifest (avyakta), and "yat param" to the transcendent Brahman that exceeds both categories entirely. The triple name used — "ananta, deveśa, jagannivāsa" (Infinite, Lord of gods, Abode of the universe) — points to Krishna's all-pervading, all-transcending, all-containing nature simultaneously.
commentary.yogananda: In this extraordinary verse, Arjuna has arrived, through the direct experience of the cosmic vision, at a recognition that advanced meditators reach only after years of sustained practice: God is not merely the creator of the universe — God IS the universe, transcends the universe, and is also the very Ground of being that the universe and non-being both rest upon. "Yat param" — that which is beyond — is the apophatic (neti-neti) dimension of the Absolute: not this, not that, yet the source of all this and all that. The mystic who can simultaneously hold "sat" (affirmation of God's immanence) and "asat" (negation of all limiting forms) and "yat param" (the transcendence of both) has attained integral spiritual vision.
commentary.goyandka: The Gītā Press commentators observe that Arjuna's address to the Lord using five epithets in this verse — mahātman, ananta, deveśa, jagannivāsa, ādikartre — constitutes a comprehensive theological affirmation. Each name reveals a dimension: Mahātman = the cosmic self; Ananta = without limit; Deveśa = sovereign over all divine powers; Jagannivāsa = the inner dwelling of the universe; Ādikartre = the uncaused first Cause. The verse then moves from names to nature: "akṣaraṃ sat ca asat ca yat param" — these four terms together describe Brahman's fourfold aspect: imperishability, existence, non-existence (the unmanifest), and the transcendent beyond all categories. This is among the most theologically dense single verses in the Gītā.

verses.sanskrit:
tvam ādidevāḥ puruṣaḥ purāṇas tvam asya viśvasya paraṃ nidhānam |
vettāsi vedyaṃ ca paraṃ ca dhāma tvayā tataṃ viśvam anantarūpa ||
verses.transliteration:
tvam ādidevāḥ puruṣaḥ purāṇaḥ tvam asya viśvasya param nidhānam |
vettā asi vedyam ca param ca dhāma tvayā tatam viśvam anantarūpa ||
verses.translation: You are the primal God, the ancient Person; You are the supreme repository of this universe; You are the Knower and the Known, the supreme Abode; by You is this universe pervaded, O Infinite-formed One.

word_breakdown.meaning: the ancient Person, the primeval Being
the supreme repository, the ultimate resting place
the Knower, the one who knows
the Known, that which is to be known
the supreme Abode, the highest dwelling
pervaded by You, spread through by You
O Infinite-formed One, of endless forms

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna heaps wonder upon wonder: You are the first God, the oldest Being, the treasury of the entire universe. And then the deepest marvel: "vettā asi vedyam ca" — You are both the Knower and the Known. There is no separation between the Seer and the Seen, the devotee and the Beloved. The mystics of every tradition have whispered this: the lover and the beloved are one. "Tvayā tatam viśvam" — by You is the universe pervaded — echoes the great statement of Gita 9.4 and takes us into the heart of non-dual vision. And the address "anantarūpa" — Infinite-formed One — reminds us that God's forms are as endless as love's creativity. Each genuine name, each sincere prayer, each true relationship touches a real face of the Formless.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The epistemological claim "vettā asi vedyam ca" — You are both the Knower and the Known — is the Advaita Vedanta position stated with perfect concision. In ordinary experience, knowledge requires a triad: knower (pramātā), the known (prameya), and the means of knowing (pramāṇa). Brahman transcends and underlies all three. The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad states: "vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt" — by whom shall the Knower be known? The Knower of all cannot be a further object of knowledge; It is the very ground of knowing. When Arjuna recognizes Krishna as both vettā and vedya, he is recognizing the Absolute's self-luminous, self-knowing nature — the "cit" aspect of Sat-Cit-Ānanda. The closing epithet "anantarūpa" balances the formless with the infinitely-formed.
commentary.yogananda: The recognition "vettā asi vedyam ca" — You are the Knower and the Known — describes the highest state of samādhi as experienced from the inside. In ordinary consciousness, the subject and object appear separate. In deep meditation, the meditator, the meditation, and the meditated upon merge into a single luminous awareness. This is what Arjuna is now perceiving about the cosmos itself: the universe is not an objective reality outside of God's awareness — God is both the awareness in which the universe appears and the universe itself. "Tvayā tatam viśvam" (the universe pervaded by You) is not pantheism alone but panentheism: God pervades the universe yet transcends it, as the ocean pervades each wave yet is not exhausted by any wave.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is a concentrated recapitulation of the key divine attributes revealed across chapters seven through ten of the Gītā. "Tvam ādidevāḥ" recalls the opening of chapter ten's vibhūti teaching. "Puruṣaḥ purāṇaḥ" appears also in 8.9 and the Puruṣasūkta. "Nidhānam" — the supreme repository or foundation — matches Gītā 9.18 where the Lord declares Himself "nidhānam" of the universe. "Vettā vedyam ca" — Knower and Known — represents the non-dual unity underlying all subject-object distinctions. The closing "anantarūpa" returns to the theme of the universal form (viśvarūpa) being described, reminding us that the hymn arises from direct vision, not theological abstraction.

verses.sanskrit:
vāyur yamo'gnir varuṇaḥ śaśāṅkaḥ prajāpatis tvaṃ prapitāmahaś ca |
namo namas te'stu sahasrakṛtvaḥ punaś ca bhūyo'pi namo namas te ||
verses.transliteration:
vāyuḥ yamaḥ agniḥ varuṇaḥ śaśāṅkaḥ prajāpatiḥ tvam prapitāmahaḥ ca |
namaḥ namaḥ te astu sahasrakṛtvaḥ punaḥ ca bhūyaḥ api namaḥ namaḥ te ||
verses.translation: You are Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the Moon, Prajapati, and the great-grandfather of all. Salutations, salutations to You — a thousand times\! And again and again, salutations, salutations to You.

word_breakdown.meaning: Yama, the god of death and dharma
Varuna, the god of the cosmic waters and cosmic law
the Moon (lit. the one with the hare mark)
Prajapati, the Lord of creatures, progenitor
the great-grandfather, the forefather of forefathers

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's hymn reaches its chant-like rhythm here — "namo namas te'stu sahasrakṛtvaḥ, punaś ca bhūyo'pi namo namas te." Say it aloud and feel the music: salutations, salutations, a thousand times, again and again, salutations, salutations. This is no longer philosophical discourse — this is the language of the heart that has run out of adequate words and so simply keeps bowing. The gods named — Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the Moon, Prajapati — are the great forces of the cosmos: breath, death, fire, water, light, and life itself. Arjuna is saying: every great power in existence is just Your face. I bow to the wind because it is You. I bow to death because it is You. I bow to fire because it is You. This is bhakti become cosmic.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The enumeration of cosmic deities — Vāyu (air/prāṇa), Yama (death/dharma), Agni (fire/transformation), Varuṇa (water/cosmic order), Śaśāṅka (moon/mind), Prajāpati (progenitor/creation), and Prapitāmaha (great-grandfather, Brahma) — is a compressed version of the vibhūti teaching of chapter ten, here delivered not by Krishna but by Arjuna himself in a moment of direct vision. This is significant: what Krishna taught in chapter ten as philosophical instruction, Arjuna now knows through direct perception. The repetition of "namaḥ" — bowing — is itself a mantra structure. The Vedic tradition uses repetition not merely for emphasis but as a meditative device that deepens the state of reverence through the act of repeated utterance.
commentary.yogananda: This verse has the unmistakable quality of a spontaneous mantra arising from the depths of an illuminated heart. The repetition of "namaḥ namaḥ" — salutations, salutations — mirrors the ancient practice of japa (repetition of the divine name) as a means of dissolving the individual ego into the ocean of divine awareness. Each name Arjuna utters — Vayu (breath-god), Agni (fire), Yama (death), Varuna (cosmic order), Moon (mind) — represents a force that permeates every moment of existence. When the soul genuinely recognizes God in all these forces, every breath becomes a prayer, every fire an altar, even death itself becomes a doorway. "Sahasrakṛtvaḥ" — a thousand times — is the mystic's way of saying: no number of salutations is adequate; I offer infinitely and still the offering is small.
commentary.goyandka: The Gītā Press commentators note that this verse moves from the abstract (akṣara, sat, asat) to the concretely named divine manifestations, showing that the Lord's supremacy encompasses both the unmanifest Absolute and all particular divine forms recognized in the Vedic tradition. Vāyu represents the prāṇic life-force; Yama, dharmic cosmic order; Agni, the purifying principle; Varuṇa, the governing principle of the cosmic waters; the Moon, the presiding deity of the mind; Prajāpati, the creative power; Prapitāmaha, Brahmā the creator who is himself the Lord's creation. The closing litany "namaḥ namaḥ te astu sahasrakṛtvaḥ punaś ca bhūyo'pi namaḥ namaḥ te" is an expression of the principle that surrender to God cannot be partial — it must be total, repeated, and ever-renewed.

verses.sanskrit:
namaḥ purastād atha pṛṣṭhatas te namo'stu te sarvata eva sarva |
anantavīryāmitavikramas tvaṃ sarvaṃ samāpnoṣi tato'si sarvaḥ ||
verses.transliteration:
namaḥ purastāt atha pṛṣṭhataḥ te namaḥ astu te sarvataḥ eva sarva |
anantavīrya amitavikramaḥ tvam sarvam samāpnoṣi tataḥ asi sarvaḥ ||
verses.translation: Salutations to You from in front and from behind\! Salutations to You from all sides, O All\! You are of infinite might and boundless valor; You pervade all and therefore You are All.

word_breakdown.meaning: salutations from in front, bowing before You
You pervade all, You encompass everything
You are All, You are everything

commentary.dadaji: Here Arjuna's hymn rises to its most complete and encompassing declaration: salutations from in front — salutations from behind — salutations from all sides — O All\! He turns in every direction and bows, because he has realized there is no direction where God is not. The logic of the final lines is stunning in its simplicity: "sarvaṃ samāpnoṣi tato'si sarvaḥ" — You pervade all, therefore You are All. Because nothing exists outside of You, You are not merely in everything — You ARE everything. This is not pantheism as a philosophical position; it is the direct realization of a man who has seen with opened eyes. When this becomes one's lived experience — not belief, but experience — the universe becomes an endless temple, and every act of living becomes an act of worship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The structure of this verse is philosophically elegant: it begins with the spatial — bowing from all directions (purastāt, pṛṣṭhataḥ, sarvataḥ) — and culminates in the ontological — "sarvaṃ samāpnoṣi tato'si sarvaḥ" (You pervade all, therefore You are All). This is the Advaita syllogism in devotional form: if Brahman pervades everything without remainder, then Brahman IS everything — there is no "leftover" world separate from Brahman. The difference between this and crude pantheism is that Krishna is not identified with the world as such, but recognized as the pervading presence in whom the world has its being. The spatial language of bowing from all directions recalls the Īśāvāsya Upaniṣad's opening: "Īśāvāsyam idam sarvam" — all this is pervaded by the Lord.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna now bows in all directions — and this is the gesture of one who has realized there is no direction outside of God. The mystic who truly knows this does not merely bow at the altar — he bows at the marketplace, bows at the mountain, bows at the face of friend and stranger alike, because everywhere is the face of the One. "Sarvam samāpnoṣi tato'si sarvaḥ" — You pervade all, therefore You are All — this is the final, unalterable conclusion of the visionary experience. Sri Ramakrishna would touch the ground and weep, saying "Mother, Mother" — because the earth was not inert matter to him but the body of the Divine. This verse is the scriptural foundation of that realization: God does not merely reside in all things — God IS all things, while simultaneously transcending all things.
commentary.goyandka: This verse brings the first movement of Arjuna's great hymn (verses 36–40) to a climactic close. The directional salutations — front, back, all sides — symbolize the completeness of surrender: there is no aspect of one's life or environment that is withheld from the divine. The epithets "anantavīrya" (infinite power) and "amitavikrama" (immeasurable valor) establish the Lord's omnipotence, grounding the final philosophical statement: "sarvam samāpnoṣi" — You pervade all. The Gītā Press commentators note that this echoes Gītā 9.4 — "mayā tatam idaṃ sarvam" (by Me is all this pervaded) — but here it is affirmed by Arjuna from direct vision rather than received as doctrine. The conclusion "tato'si sarvaḥ" — therefore You are All — is the Vedantic mahāvākya expressed through the language of bhakti: You are Brahman, and Brahman is All.

verses.sanskrit: sakheti matvā prasabhaṃ yad uktaṃ he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakheti | ajānatā mahimānaṃ tavedam mayā pramādāt praṇayena vāpi ||
verses.transliteration: sakhā iti matvā prasabhaṃ yad uktaṃ he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakhā iti | ajānatā mahimānaṃ tava idam mayā pramādāt praṇayena vā api ||
verses.translation: Whatever I have said rashly, thinking of You as a friend — 'O Krishna, O Yadava, O friend!' — out of ignorance of Your greatness, through negligence or through love...

word_breakdown.meaning: thinking of You as a friend

commentary.dadaji: This verse is one of the most touching moments in all of the Gita — Arjuna, still trembling from the vision of the Cosmic Form, looks back on all the years he called Krishna 'friend' with such easy familiarity, and his heart fills with tender remorse. He does not condemn himself harshly, but offers his past words as they were — spoken out of love, yet from ignorance. The Lord does not want cold formality from us; He wants our love. But Arjuna is teaching us here that love itself deepens when we begin to understand Who it is we love. Even the affectionate names 'O Krishna, O Yadava' become sacred when spoken with full awareness. Let our devotion grow, not diminish, as our understanding of the Divine grows.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Arjuna's confession in this verse beautifully mirrors the Upanishadic teaching that Brahman, though immanent and intimate as one's own Self — closer than the closest — is simultaneously the transcendent Absolute before whom even the greatest sages bow. The Kena Upanishad declares: That which is not thought by the mind, but by which the mind thinks — know That alone as Brahman. Arjuna had treated this very Brahman as a charioteer and friend. His words 'ajānatā mahimānam' — out of ignorance of Your greatness — echo the Vedantic understanding of avidyā: it is not malice but ignorance that veils the true nature of the Supreme. The verse is a profound confession of the human condition before the Divine.
commentary.yogananda: In the cosmic vision, Arjuna's small personal self was overwhelmed by the infinite Self. Now he looks back on all his casual conversations with Krishna — the battlefield discussions, the moments of laughter and companionship — and sees them in a completely new light. The friendship was real and sacred, but it was lived at one level of consciousness; the cosmic vision has now lifted him to another. This is the transformative nature of genuine spiritual experience: it does not destroy the personal love — it transfigures it. 'Through negligence or through love' — Arjuna's love was pure, and God accepted it. But now that love is expanded to include the whole cosmos.
commentary.goyandka: This verse begins Arjuna's prayer of apology and supplication that extends through verse 44. The word prasabham indicates boldness bordering on presumption — Arjuna freely addressed the Supreme Lord as one addresses a friend, without the reverence befitting His infinite majesty. The word pramādāt (negligence) and praṇayena (affection) together show that Arjuna's casual speech arose both from inattentiveness and from genuine love — both are acknowledged honestly. The traditional commentators note that this kind of self-examination and repentance purifies the devotee's heart. It is always appropriate to seek forgiveness from the Lord when one recognizes one's own limitations.

verses.sanskrit: yac cāvahāsārtham asatkṛto'si vihāraśayyāsanabhojanādiṣu | eko'thavāpy acyuta tatsamakṣaṃ tat kṣāmaye tvām aham aprameyam ||
verses.transliteration: yat ca avahāsārtham asatkṛtaḥ asi vihāra śayyā āsana bhojana ādiṣu | ekaḥ atha vā api acyuta tat samakṣam tat kṣāmaye tvām aham aprameyam ||
verses.translation: And however You may have been insulted in jest, while resting, sitting, eating, or playing — whether alone or in the presence of others — O Acyuta, for all that I ask Your forgiveness, O Immeasurable.

word_breakdown.meaning: and for the sake of jest, for the purpose of joking
and so forth, among other activities
O Infallible One, O Acyuta (one who does not fall)
in the presence of others, before witnesses
I ask Your forgiveness for that

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's memory is thorough and humble — he lists every ordinary setting of their friendship: resting, sleeping, sitting together, sharing meals. In all of those intimate moments he may have laughed at Krishna, joked with Him, perhaps even teased or mocked Him playfully, as friends do. And now he asks forgiveness for every one of those moments. There is something deeply beautiful here: he addresses Krishna as 'Acyuta' — the Infallible One — even as he confesses his own very fallible behavior. And he calls Him 'aprameyam' — Immeasurable — the one who cannot be weighed or defined. He is measuring his own smallness against the Immeasurable, and humbly asking grace.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Vedantic insight here is subtle: Arjuna is recognizing that the Brahman he has seen in the cosmic vision was always present in the friend he called Krishna. When the Mandukya Upanishad declares Brahman as 'prajñānam Brahma' — consciousness itself — it points to the same truth. Every moment of companionship with Krishna was a moment of living with the Absolute. Arjuna's jest and laughter at meals were addressed to the very ground of Being. The address 'Acyuta' is significant: it means the one who does not slip — implying that however much Arjuna may have treated Krishna casually, Krishna never wavered in His divine nature. The Immeasurable remained Immeasurable throughout.
commentary.yogananda: The beautiful word 'aprameyam' — the Immeasurable — is a key to understanding this verse. The Cosmic Self that Arjuna has just witnessed cannot be measured, cannot be contained in any concept or form. Yet this same Immeasurable One sat with Arjuna at meals, slept under the same stars, laughed at the same jokes. The mystery of the Divine condescension — God taking the form of a friend — is one of the most profound gifts given to humanity. Arjuna is overwhelmed by the realization of what he had all along and did not fully know. His request for forgiveness is also, in its essence, a prayer of gratitude.
commentary.goyandka: This verse completes the list of occasions on which Arjuna may have been disrespectful: not only in speech (verse 41) but also through bodily behavior during the ordinary activities of daily life. The classical commentators observe that by naming these activities — vihāra, śayyā, āsana, bhojana — Arjuna is covering every waking moment of their long friendship, indicating that his request for forgiveness is total and comprehensive. He asks to be pardoned by 'aprameyam' — addressing the Lord as the Immeasurable — which is itself an act of devotion recognizing that even the Lord's capacity to forgive is without limit.

verses.sanskrit: pitāsi lokasya carācarasya tvam asya pūjyaś ca gurur garīyān | na tvatsamo'sty abhyadhikaḥ kuto'nyo lokatraye'py apratimaprabhāva ||
verses.transliteration: pitā asi lokasya carācarasya tvam asya pūjyaḥ ca guruḥ garīyān | na tvat samaḥ asti abhyadhikaḥ kutaḥ anyaḥ loka traye api apratimaprabhāva ||
verses.translation: You are the Father of this moving and unmoving world; You are its teacher and the most venerable Guru; there is none equal to You — how then could there be another greater? O You of incomparable power, in all the three worlds.

word_breakdown.meaning: of the world, of all worlds
of moving and unmoving (all of creation)
the most weighty, the greatest, most venerable
O You of incomparable power and glory

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna now lifts his eyes from his own smallness to the supreme greatness of the Lord. He is Father — not of one nation or lineage, but of carācara, the moving and the still, all that lives and all that does not move. He is Guru, and not merely a great teacher — He is garīyān, the most weighty, the one whose word carries ultimate authority. Arjuna says there is no one equal to You — how could anyone be greater? This is the natural fruit of the cosmic vision: the heart overflows in praise. When we glimpse even a fraction of God's glory, all comparison falls away. There is simply the Lord, and there is everything else, which is also the Lord.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The title 'pitā' — Father — given to the Lord here has Upanishadic resonance. The Taittiriya Upanishad invokes the Supreme as 'pitā naḥ pāhi' — O Father, protect us. The word 'guru garīyān' — the most weighty Guru — places the Lord above all human teachers, as the very source of all teaching. Advaita Vedanta would point out that this acknowledgment is not merely theistic devotion; it is recognition that the supreme Awareness behind all creation is also the supreme Teacher — it is consciousness that illumines all knowledge. The declaration 'na tvat samaḥ asti' — there is none equal to You — is simultaneously a philosophical statement and an act of surrender.
commentary.yogananda: When Arjuna calls Krishna the Father of carācara — the moving and the unmoving — he is recognizing what the great saints and seers have always known: the Cosmic Consciousness is the parent of all existence, from the pulsing galaxy to the still stone. The phrase 'apratimaprabhāva' — of incomparable power — captures this perfectly. There is no standard by which to measure God's glory because every standard is itself contained within that glory. Arjuna's mind, expanded by the cosmic vision, is now expressing these truths not as doctrine but as direct perception. This is the fruit of genuine mystical experience: one sees the truth and simply states it.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's hymn reaches its theological summit here. By declaring the Lord 'pitā' (Father) of all, 'pūjya' (worthy of worship), and 'guru garīyān' (the greatest of all Gurus), he establishes the complete superiority of the Divine over every relationship and every authority in creation. The logical argument is elegant: if there is no one equal to the Lord, then the very category of greater than the Lord becomes meaningless — kutaḥ anyaḥ — how could another exist? The epithet 'apratimaprabhāva' — of incomparable glory — ties the verse back to the direct experience of the Cosmic Form that Arjuna has just witnessed.

verses.sanskrit: tasmāt praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyaṃ prasādaye tvām aham īśam īḍyam | piteva putrasya sakheva sakhyuḥ priyaḥ priyāyārhasi deva soḍhum ||
verses.transliteration: tasmāt praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyam prasādaye tvām aham īśam īḍyam | pitā iva putrasya sakhā iva sakhyuḥ priyaḥ priyāyāḥ arhasi deva soḍhum ||
verses.translation: Therefore, bowing and prostrating my body, I seek Your grace, O Lord worthy of praise. As a father bears with a son, as a friend with a friend, as a beloved with a loved one — please bear with me, O God.

word_breakdown.meaning: prostrating my body, laying my body down
I seek Your grace, I propitiate You
with a son, of a son
a beloved with a loved one
to bear with, to tolerate, to forgive

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most tender verses in the entire Gita. Arjuna prostrates himself fully — body laid on the ground — and then, in the most human of all prayers, he asks God to forgive him the way a father forgives a child, a friend forgives a friend, a beloved forgives a loved one. These are the three greatest relationships of intimacy: parent and child, friend and friend, lover and beloved. And he asks the Lord to respond from within all three of them. This is the genius of bhakti — it does not abandon the human heart's capacity for relationship; it offers all of it to God. Arjuna pours every form of love he knows at Krishna's feet and says: please bear with me.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The three similes — father and son, friend and friend, beloved and loved one — correspond to what the Bhagavata tradition identifies as three of the great bhāvas (devotional moods): vātsalya bhāva (parental love), sakhya bhāva (friendship), and mādhurya bhāva (love between lovers). Arjuna invokes all three at once, which the commentators find remarkable. Even as he prostrates physically — 'praṇidhāya kāyam' — his prayer is thoroughly relational. The Upanishadic teaching on the relationship of the individual self to Brahman finds its most intimate expression in this moment of surrender: the ātman lays itself entirely before the Paramātman and asks only for grace.
commentary.yogananda: The great spiritual masters teach that God responds to the sincere cry of the devotee more surely than any parent, friend, or beloved. Arjuna has now made the complete journey in this chapter: from wonder (seeing the cosmic form), to terror, to praise, to remorse, to full surrender. Each stage was necessary. The cosmic vision was given to him not to crush him but to transform him, and the transformation is now complete in this prostration. 'Soḍhum' — to bear with me — is the prayer of every soul that has glimpsed its own limitation before the Infinite. God always says yes to such a prayer.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna uses three analogies for Divine forbearance that are perfectly calibrated. A father's love is unconditional despite a child's immaturity. A friend's love is forgiving despite a companion's lapses. A beloved's love is patient even when affection is expressed imperfectly. By invoking all three, Arjuna is asking the Lord to respond from the fullness of every loving relationship that the human heart knows. The physical act of prostration — 'praṇidhāya kāyam' — combined with the inner humility of 'prasādaye' (I seek Your grace) constitutes the complete act of śaraṇāgati, total self-surrender to the Lord.

verses.sanskrit: adṛṣṭapūrvaṃ hṛṣito'smi dṛṣṭvā bhayena ca pravyathitaṃ mano me | tad eva me darśaya deva rūpaṃ prasīda deveśa jagannivāsa ||
verses.transliteration: adṛṣṭapūrvam hṛṣitaḥ asmi dṛṣṭvā bhayena ca pravyathitam manaḥ me | tat eva me darśaya deva rūpam prasīda deveśa jagannivāsa ||
verses.translation: I am delighted by seeing what was never seen before, and yet my mind is troubled with fear. Show me that familiar form, O God — have mercy, O Lord of gods, O Abode of the universe.

word_breakdown.meaning: what was never seen before, unprecedented
I am delighted, I am glad
that very, that same (other, gentle) form
have mercy, be gracious, be pleased
O Lord of gods, O God of gods
O Abode of the universe, O dwelling-place of all

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna is completely honest about his inner state: he holds two things simultaneously — delight and fear. He is thrilled by what he has seen, as any soul would be who has glimpsed God in His fullness. And he is deeply frightened, as any honest human being would be. He does not pretend the fear away. He simply says: both are true. I was delighted. I am disturbed. Now please — show me Your gentle face. The three names he uses here are magnificent: 'deva' (the shining God), 'deveśa' (Lord even of the gods), 'jagannivāsa' (the Abode of the entire universe). He calls out to the Infinite by these vast names — and asks for the personal, intimate, four-armed, gentle form.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse captures the dialectic at the heart of the encounter with the Absolute: the experience of the numinous is simultaneously fascinating and terrible — what Rudolf Otto called the mysterium tremendum et fascinans. Arjuna's 'hṛṣitaḥ' (delight) and 'bhayena pravyathitam' (mind trembling with fear) are two sides of the same coin. The Katha Upanishad says the Ātman is not reached by the weak — but neither is it peacefully comprehended in its fullness by the ordinary mind. Arjuna's request to see the gentle form again is not weakness; it is wisdom. The human mind can only assimilate the Infinite gradually, through the medium of a beloved personal form.
commentary.yogananda: The two emotions Arjuna describes — delight and fear — are the hallmarks of genuine mystical experience. Every soul that has touched cosmic consciousness knows this paradox: it is the most wonderful and the most overwhelming experience simultaneously. The joy comes from recognizing one's own deepest nature; the fear comes from the annihilation of the small self that clings to its separateness. Arjuna is asking, in essence, come back to me in a form I can love without losing myself entirely. This is not a retreat from God — it is the heart's prayer for a relationship that is sustainable, intimate, and enduring.
commentary.goyandka: The address 'jagannivāsa' — O Abode of the universe — is theologically significant: even as Arjuna asks the Lord to contract His infinite form into the familiar four-armed Viṣṇu form, he acknowledges that this same Lord is the very ground and dwelling-place of everything. The request for the gentle form is not a denial of the cosmic form; it is a petition for the descent of the Infinite into a form that human love and devotion can embrace. The three divine addresses — deva, deveśa, jagannivāsa — themselves constitute a hymn, moving from the personal to the cosmic to the all-pervading.

verses.sanskrit: kirīṭinaṃ gadinaṃ hastakṛtaṃ icchāmi tvāṃ draṣṭum ahaṃ tathaiva | tenaiva rūpeṇa caturbhujena sahasrabāho bhava viśvamūrte ||
verses.transliteration: kirīṭinam gadinam hastakṛtam icchāmi tvām draṣṭum aham tathā eva | tena eva rūpeṇa caturbhujena sahasrabāho bhava viśvamūrte ||
verses.translation: I wish to see You just as before — with crown, with mace, and with discus in hand. O Thousand-armed, O Universal Form, please become again that four-armed form.

word_breakdown.meaning: wearing the crown, bearing the diadem
with discus in hand (cakra held by hand)
just as before, in the same manner
O Universal Form, O whose form is the universe

commentary.dadaji: There is something deeply moving in Arjuna's request here. He is addressing the Lord simultaneously by two names that seem to contradict each other: 'sahasrabāho' (O Thousand-armed — the cosmic, infinite form) and asking Him to become caturbhuja (four-armed — the familiar, personal form). He uses both names in the same breath. He is not trying to make the Infinite disappear; he is asking it to compress itself into something he can approach, embrace, and love. And the Lord, in His infinite grace, will do exactly that. There is no greater miracle than God choosing to be personal for the sake of a devoted heart.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The iconographic details Arjuna requests — crown (kirīṭa), mace (gadā), and discus (cakra) — correspond to the established form of Lord Viṣṇu in the four-armed manifestation, which is itself a mediating form between the formless Absolute and the world of human perception. The Pañcarātra tradition understands these four-armed forms as vyūha manifestations — purposeful expressions of the Divine for the sake of the devotees' worship and meditation. Arjuna's address 'viśvamūrte' (Universal Form) even as he asks for the caturbhuja (four-armed) form shows his understanding that the two are not separate: the personal is an aspect of the universal.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's request for the four-armed form is, at the deepest level, a request for relationship. The cosmic vision showed him the impersonal, universal aspect of God — infinite, all-devouring, beyond all names and forms. This is the nirguna Brahman of the Upanishads. But Arjuna's heart longs for the saguna — the personal, approachable, lovable God. Both are real. The masters teach that the personal and the impersonal are not two different Gods; they are two dimensions of the same Reality. The devotee approaches God personally; the jñāni approaches Him through wisdom. Arjuna is choosing the path of personal love, which is itself the subject of Krishna's teaching in the final verses of this chapter.
commentary.goyandka: The verse shows Arjuna's clear visualization of the Viṣṇu form he desires — crown, mace, and discus represent the well-established caturvyūha iconography familiar to all Vaiṣṇava devotees. It is worth noting the touching paradox: he addresses Krishna as 'sahasrabāho' (Thousand-armed, i.e., the cosmic form itself) while petitioning Him to appear as 'caturbhuja' (four-armed). The cosmic form has not disappeared from Arjuna's understanding — he holds both the universal and the personal in simultaneous awareness. This is the mark of a mature devotee who has truly absorbed the vision of Chapter 11.

verses.sanskrit: mayā prasannena tavārjunedaṃ rūpaṃ paraṃ darśitam ātmayogāt | tejomayaṃ viśvam anantam ādyaṃ yan me tvadanyena na dṛṣṭapūrvam ||
verses.transliteration: mayā prasannena tava arjuna idam rūpam param darśitam ātmayogāt | tejomayam viśvam anantam ādyam yat me tvadanyena na dṛṣṭapūrvam ||
verses.translation: Out of grace for you, O Arjuna, this supreme form has been shown to you by Me through My own Yoga Power — radiant, universal, infinite, primeval — which no one but you has ever seen before.

word_breakdown.meaning: by Me, gracious, out of My graciousness
for you, out of love for you
has been shown, has been revealed
through My own Yoga Power, by My divine power

commentary.dadaji: With great tenderness, the Lord now answers Arjuna's prayer. He makes it clear: this cosmic vision was a gift — 'prasannena,' given out of grace and love. Arjuna did not earn it through austerity or Vedic study; he received it because the Lord willed it and because Arjuna's heart was open. The Lord describes this form with four magnificent words: tejomayam (radiant), viśvam (universal), anantam (infinite), ādyam (primeval — the original from which all else flows). And then He says something extraordinary: no one before you has seen this. Arjuna is uniquely blessed — not because he is superior, but because he is surrendered and beloved.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'ātmayogāt' — through My own Yoga Power — is philosophically significant. It means the cosmic vision was not produced by any external means; it arose from the Lord's own divine nature, expressed as yoga-śakti, the power of divine Self-awareness. The Isha Upanishad declares 'Īśāvāsyam idam sarvam' — all this is pervaded by the Lord — and what Arjuna saw was precisely this pervasion. The four adjectives — tejomayam, viśvam, anantam, ādyam — correspond to the Upanishadic characterizations of Brahman as light (jyotir Brahma), as all-pervading (sarvam khalv idam Brahma), as infinite (anantam Brahma), and as the original source (ādyam).
commentary.yogananda: The Lord's words 'prasannena' — out of grace — reveal the fundamental truth about mystical experience: it cannot be manufactured or forced. It is given. Paramahansa Yogananda often taught that cosmic consciousness descends on the prepared devotee as the free gift of God's love. Arjuna had prepared himself through years of discipleship, and in this supreme moment of the battlefield, with his heart fully open, the Infinite poured through. 'No one but you has seen this' is not an exclusive claim — it is the intimacy of every unique God-devotee relationship: each soul's vision of the Divine is irreducibly personal and unrepeatable.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord's declaration that this vision is unprecedented — 'na dṛṣṭapūrvam' — is sometimes questioned by commentators who note that great sages and the gods themselves contemplate the Lord's form. Śrī Śaṅkarācārya interprets this as referring specifically to this particular manifestation of the Cosmic Form in its complete universality, shown by the Lord through His ātmayoga — His divine power operating spontaneously and freely. The verse establishes that the cosmic vision of Chapter 11 is a supreme gift of grace, not an achievement of spiritual practice, which sets up the teaching of verse 54 that only through ananya bhakti is such a vision accessible.

verses.sanskrit: na vedayajñādhyayanair na dānair na ca kriyābhir na tapobhir ugraiḥ | evaṃrūpaḥ śakya ahaṃ nṛloke draṣṭuṃ tvadanyena kurupravīra ||
verses.transliteration: na veda yajña adhyayanaiḥ na dānaiḥ na ca kriyābhiḥ na tapobhiḥ ugraiḥ | evam rūpaḥ śakyaḥ aham nṛloke draṣṭum tvadanyena kurupravīra ||
verses.translation: Not through the Vedas, not through sacrifice, not through study, not through gifts, not through rituals, not through severe austerities — in this form can I be seen in the world of men by anyone other than you, O best of Kurus.

word_breakdown.meaning: not by Vedas, sacrifice, and study
in the world of men, in human existence
to be seen, to be beheld
O best of Kurus, O hero of the Kuru clan

commentary.dadaji: The Lord now makes a statement that must have staggered the tradition: none of the great means — not the Vedas, not sacrifice, not learning, not charity, not ritual, not even the most fierce austerities — can produce this vision of the Cosmic Form in the human world. Arjuna received it not through any of these, but through his relationship with Krishna, through love, through openness. This is an extraordinary teaching. It does not dismiss the Vedas or austerity — but it places something above them: the direct grace of the Lord, given through devotion. The path of bhakti, which will be made explicit in verse 54, is already being prepared here.
